reviewText:
F.E.A.R 3 is the last game in the F.E.A.R  series thus far, releasing in mid 2011 on PC, Xbox360 and PS3 being developed by Day 1 Studios, the same guys which developed the first F.E.A.R on PS3 and Xbox360.

The bulk of the gameplay is the same as the previous titles with a few minor changes.  The main one being a change to how the cover system work. In the previous games you used to be able to tilt your character’s head around corners in order to shoot, F.E.A.R 3 adds a peeking system, where you can hug up against any sort of cover and drop your headup and down whilst also moving side to side in order to shoot from cover. This for me felt a lot easier to handle than the previous version and is a really nice change.  The rest of the game play is very much the same, I was a little bit let down by the gun mechanics however, I praised the first game heavily due to how the gun play feels so fluid and responsive, sadly in 3 I had a lot of trouble aiming whilst looking down the sight and spent the majority of the time shooting from the hip. This was mainly because the hit detection on the bullets is quite a bit off, you can sometimes get a direct hit on an enemies head and nothing happens.  There is only one new weapon to be introduced in the game too, a freezing gun which you obtain by overcoming one of the many fights with the same boss throughout the single player campaign mode.

Graphically, F.E.A.R 3 looks OK. It is 4 years old at this point and you can tell it is part of the last generation of gaming, but it still holds it’s own compared to games released around that time. The texture quality is just bog standard OK again, where the F.E.A.R series does well, is the animation of the characters, they all have a very good ragdoll effect to them, meaning death animations are all on point and can result in some unique positions.

F.E.A.R 3 isn’t hard when playing on the medium settings; FPS vetrans need to bump it up to hard mode for it to be even slightly challenging; I don’t think I died more than two times throughout the whole game which is something to be said given the amount of bosses you have to fight.  Some levels are actually made significantly easier since they give you a mech suit to use which whilst it is absolutely satisfying to blow up enemies at point blank range with missiles, it does make the level seem somewhat pointless as there is no challenge and just feels more like a time block than anything else.

Unlike the previous games; the levels in F.E.A.R 3 are very linear and leave very little for the player to explore and find secrets/collectables. There is one collectable on each level which is randomly placed every time you play, but there isn’t extra bits of lore/plot to be found from hacking computers, or finding documents;  something which I did miss as the story in this game is actually somewhat interesting compared to the last games.

A single play through this game took me just under four hours; where you will get the majority of your replay ability from F.E.A.R 3 is the co-op mode and challenge system. This is the first F.E.A.R game to have any sort of co-op mode in and it does it very well. The multiplayer missions feel very much like Killing Floor, so if you enjoyed that, you will get some enjoyment out of the F.E.A.R 3 multiplayer too.

I only had one technical issue whilst playing, and that was when playing with more than on screen, your mouse will sometimes exit the screen you are playing on and when you click to shoot, you’ll minimize to your desktop as it has roamed onto another screen – this became a real annoyance on the latter levels when you have very little time to react to things. I was unable to find a fix for this online so be warned!

To sum up, F.E.A.R 3 is definitely not as good as the previous two games, but it does offer something a bit different. The price on Steam of £12,99 is a bit steep given the shortness of the single player, but you can pick up the entire F.E.A.R collection from Bundle Stars for a mere £3.26 - https://www.bundlestars.com/en/bundle/fear-bundle  meaning you can’t really go wrong with picking the title up there.  Going off that, I am only going to recommend F.E.A.R 3 when it is on sale.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
FEAR 3 represents what is wrong with many 'modernization' processes of games. It takes everything that people liked about the first few games in the series and just replaces or modifies them to work with current trends, such as in this case regenerating health, co-op, perks... However, I would also argue FEAR 3 is not a bad game. If you're looking for a game akin to FEAR 1 or 2, this unfortunately is not it. It also is pretty lacking in the horror department. It's not scary, or even really atmospheric, though it attempts to be. What it is though, is a pretty fun multiplayer experience.

The story will probably ♥♥♥♥-off long-time fans. Without going too deep into spoilers, the story basically focuses mostly on Fettel, the antagonist from the first game. The story's already kind of in a mess from the get-go, as we have things from psychic powers, clones, the fact our two main characters are the sons of the series main antagonist Alma, and just other plot elements that just scream they're so bad. But it's not badly written to be fair, and if you kind of turn off your brain it's kind of stupid entertainment. But you really shouldn't be playing this game for the story.

The campaign should last for about 5-7 hours, with some highs and lows, but that in no way compares to the previous two games. The co-op helps make it a bit more fun, for better or worse. The two brothers play completely differently though, with Pointman basically being your typical action hero with the guns and the slide-kicks, and Fettel being actually surprisingly rather fresh, being a psychic man who can levitate enemies, possess them, shoot energy blasts, and more. Honestly, both are pretty fun, but I have to hand it to Fettel as for a game with very little inspiration behind it, his gameplay is actually rather original for this sort of game and fun.

But it's not the campaign you should be buying FEAR 3 for, as weird as that might sound. I find most people never delve into the multiplayer modes in this game. And it's sensible, as the campaign is disappointing and usually multiplayer modes are tagged on without much thought or effort, so it's probably nothing special, right?

Well, that's wrong, as it turns out the multiplayer modes in this game are actually the best part of the game.

I can't even count how many friends who got FEAR 3 that ended up loving the multiplayer modes and hating the campaign. Let me explain; The campaign lacks tension, and often is a bit repetitive, on-top of the fact it just feels rather uninspired most of the time, its horror elements fail, and its action sequences aren't particularly great. But something FEAR 3 does surprisingly well is understand the fun elements of multiplayer shooters. Hell, some of the multiplayer modes are even far more tense and more horror-like than anything in the campaign.

Multiplayer is split into four modes, and all four are pretty fun for up to four-players either locally or online. Each mode has different maps. One mode has you all as ghost phantoms who possess bodies and try to kill other enemies and your friends to collect souls, most souls at the end of a wave wins the round, and at the end of all waves, person with the most rounds won wins. Another mode has you in an open arena with multiple areas to station yourself in as you and friends fight hordes of enemies that come in waves, boarding up windows and between waves going out to collect supplies. It's a sort of rip-off of Zombie mode from CoD, but it has some interesting twists, such as Alma, who you should not look at as she'll cause randomized effects against you, ranging from just downing you to making you see your friends as enemies, making the screen go black, or teleporting you to another random point on the map. Or a fog, that gets thicker and thicker as the waves go on, and an unseen red-light monster lurks in the deeper parts of the fog... And in yet another mode, you and up to three friends run away from a giant wall of death. Really challenging, frantic, tense, panic-worthy, but a lot of fun as a lot of enemies get tossed your way and you only get small breathers to quickly recollect supplies before the wall is out it again. A race from death and survival that is both primal but also strategic and fun.

The game also looks pretty good, and the PC port is well-done. Music works, but nothing outside of the credits song sticks as being particularly memorable.

FEAR 3 is against most everything the FEAR series stands for, but if you can look over that and a disappointing campaign, I guarantee you there's some multiplayer fun here that may be worth experiencing.

reviewText:
The first F.E.A.R. was an outstanding masterpiece. The two following expansion packs were so so.
F.E.A.R. 2 was great in my opinion. The game had a crappy story although the pacing of the game was good, it also featured a smart AI, it had amazing visuals (fire effect, smoke, explosion, close combat, firefights, etc), some great scares and a convincing atmosphere, etc.

F.E.A.R 3 features an even smarter AI. The enemy soldiers are quick to take cover, switch positions, retreat, suppress you, throw grenades, flank you and charge you when they can. There's also plenty of enemy chatter that you can hear which allows you to anticipate some of your enemies' movements. They will also call you out if you are hiding for too long.

Needless to say, the AI as advanced as it is in Killzone 2,3 which features the smartest FPS AI to date. In fact, the AI is sometimes so smart, it becomes punishing. Plus there's no blind fire option, you make peek out of your cover and unleash small burst but you will almost certainly get return fire. Your screen WILL stay red for an extended period of time after being shot at. You may also chose to stay in cover until the red screen goes away, but sometimes you can get approached by a guy with a shotgun who will blow you away.

Your flashlight will also expose you to your enemies just like in the first game. However, I tested this further and found out that the enemies will react to your flashlight even IF they do not face you, meaning they react to your flashlight being turned on, they don't react to the flashlight necessarily because the AI field of vision picks it up.

The cover system is outstanding and I can only wish that most if not all FPS featured this kind of cover system. The Killzone franchise invented this realistic cover system first though.
When you take cover, you do not get the chance to view yourself in the third person perspective nor will you be able to magically see everything that is going on around you. This time, the only way for you to view your surroundings is to peek from a cover. It is too bad there's no leaning option, but you can lean easily when in cover.

The bullet time is back and it works the same way it did in F.E.A.R 2, although it drains slightly faster, at first at least.

Oh and also, Paxton Fettel is back! Damn did I miss his voice. They all deserve to die..." Although

reviewText:
If you like shooters it's okay. If you like F.E.A.R. it's bad.

This game should have never been called fear. I say this not just for the spurious representation of the classic fear games, but for the fact the game is not scary. The original fear is in my option a revolutionary game, the level of detail and thought put into it was tremendous. This game however has little to none to connect this to the original fear.   The Replicants are gone. The invisible assassins are gone. This does not seem to be a fear game, and that is a good way to put it as this game seems more like another. Call of duty clone is not a term that should be used likely but the similarities are far too obvious, nearly all of the original mechanics of fear(health/armor, specialized weapons) have been torn out to put in call of duty mechanics(health regeneration, riot shield, flash grenades.).

The first level says it all for me. I start crawling through the jail not sure what going to happen when I realized. It's too bright. The first “scare” was little more than an special effect and Alma saying hello. Next a power failure, finally some scary scenes. However before one jump scare the lights come back on. Finally, I as the middle of a firefight when I see an enemy above me on a catwalk. My thoughts went as follows. “Crud, im going to have to walk around to get at him.. wait, this a fear game, there quality games, I should be able to shoot through the floor!” this is when I realized this is no fear game.

And it really isn’t a fear game. Like the other fear games, it was not made on the LithTech engine. This engine gave fear so much more than other games. I already notice several missing refinements. The levels where sloppy. In the first you knew what way to go. It gave you plenty of lighting hints movements and other cues to push you in the right direction. I got lost many times in this one.

Lastly the story, to be honest, If you did not play Fear 2 you would not care about 70% of this story. Truthfully If point man where to just walk away the same ending would have happened.  There are many issues with the story that I could argue but I think the main issue I had was Alma. All the way through the fear games Alma has been set as a boogeyman. And even though a new creep one was created for this she is still this silent super being, beging in the shadows in the first game was okay. This was the story of the story, but now that we have reached the end her character barely develops from being a bump in the night.

reviewText:
Remember F.E.A.R. when it first came out and you wanted to play it even though your system couldn't even handle it?  Perhaps, that was not the case for you, but it was for me.  Eventually, I was able to run it with decent hardware and I never looked back.

F.E.A.R. stepped into the seen in slow-mo and then it took the first-person shooter genre by storm, tailored to shooter and survival-horror fans.  F.E.A.R. 3, while the weaker follow-up to the F.E.A.R. series still holds up as an atmospheric game with solid gunplay and an interestingly shocking ending like its predecessor.  Some may complain that the formula is becoming boring and stale, but it is still a perfectly decent addition to the franchise.

As a fan of the Dead Space series, I found F.E.A.R. 3 to have a commanding presence when it comes to atmosphere.  I would argue that F.E.A.R. 3 nails the atmosphere and overall eerie-filled environments better than Dead Space 3. The attentional to detail is more adequate in some areas than others, but it has enough going in that department to earn a ribbon.

The gunplay is rock-solid, which makes gameplay worthwhile.  Along with the cover system that lets you peek while in cover, quickly lean to the opposite side and aim, it nails the cover-system just right.  For those that are looking for a more conventional F.E.A.R. 3 tactic and approach to gameplay, it is still all there and nothing much has changed if you want to use slow-mo and the run-and-gun variety.

Even on the easiest difficulty, F.E.A.R. 3 can present some difficulty spikes.  A franchise that basically expects a player to run-and-gun using the slow-mo function, you could be taken down quickly on normal difficulty.  It asks you to be tactical while using slow-mo.  It is slightly different from F.E.A.R. 1 in that you are not only running into singular rooms, using slow-mo, and unloading.  There are plenty of cover usage so you will need to run from one cover to another while using slow-mo.  Think of it as a Chinese action film with lots of gun-fighting.  It can be quite satisifying at times, but the variation comes in with using cover to get to where you need to go without dying outright.  I hear it is a common complaint among the series' fans, but I did not find a major issue with it.

F.E.A.R. 3 is far from great and it is worth noting that it is not spectacular as the original F.E.A.R.  Either way, it manages to be a perfectly decent addition to the series without presenting any major quams.  It is successful at being a solid first-person shooter with the well-known F.E.A.R. elements.  While I cannot comment on the co-operative play because I have no experience in it, F.E.A.R. 3 offers enough there to warrant a purchase on a decent sale.

I paid $5 for it and I thought that it was worth it.  I cannot say for sure if it would have been worth $10 though.

It's a rock-solid game to the series.  Just do not expect another F.E.A.R. 1 and you will enjoy it for what it offers.

Game on,
Elann

Rating: 7 out of 10

reviewText:
The history of F.E.A.R's development has swapped hands through practically every expansion and installment and which each one, a new take on the franchise was created. Most, if nearly all, fans of the series consider the first F.E.A.R to be the 'best' due to its thick, tense atmosphere and and engaging combat and I agree to a point. F.E.A.R 1 still out plays most shooters and horror games today!

So with that legacy and high standard already set from the get go, it'd cetainly be a challenge to meet it again, especially in the hands of a different developer! As a result, many people tend to look down on F.E.A.R 3 as being a 'generic' CoD clone and this couldn't be more of a lie!

F.E.A.R 3 is certainly different to its predecessor in terms of pace, atmosphere and horror. It's not what I'd call a horror game and that may be a turn off for most. But what it lacks in creepy it certainly MORE than makes up for in fun and replayability! The standard of combat is very much maintained despite the (shock horror) regenerating health and cover systems. The guns have a very engaging feel to them, enemies being gibbed and pinned to the wall or heads popping to the lined up headshot let you know you're in a F.E.A.R game! Regenerating health seems more fitting to the title as the levels are not as big and large scale combat happens a lot more frequently, not giving you time to look for those hidden health boosts in previous games. Cover system can be taken or left, it's simply another option of play style which leads to another staple feature of F.E.A.R 3. Pointman? Fettel? or both? You can now play as the big bad lil' brother in F.E.A.R, who comes with his own unique playstyle of possessing enemies and harassing them with supernatural powers. This can lead to great gameplay choices like choosing who to possess based on position, type of enemy or weapon they're carrying. Pointman's slow mo reflexes and neo martial arts return also adding more choices to how you take out your enemies. While either character is a blast to play with, the real fun and where the game truly shines comes when both monsters are on the field together in the form of co-op. The whole game can be played together where the two brothers tackle the campaign in a ironically funny way. Pointman can slow down time to help Fettel with his possessions or Fettel can quickly take out a strong enemy harassing pointman by either suspending him in midway for Pointman to finish or for Fettel to possess! There's a rewarding and competitive points system in each playthrough to decide who ultimately is the favourite son! Some actions can be performed where you greedily obtain all the points of a situation or share them with your brother depending on the bond with your 'brother' (after all this a game about the strength of 'family' :P)

Seeing Alma subtely appear through out levels is a nice nod to her freaky apperances in previous F.E.A.R games and it was always a cool thing to find! Some level designs and moments can lead to an eerie feeling, but nothing you'd expect from 1, still it's nice to have it there, it doesn't feel like some tacked on thing to a shooter.

Multiplayer is surprisingly engaging, with fun unique game modes like 'JUST F**KING RUN' where you and your team are being chased by a fog of screaming death and your goal is to just keep running towards the goal while taking out enemy obstacles in your path! Though you can't get held up for too long and the fog is ever approaching! Contractions revolves around your team mates stock piling crates found in the map that provide you with weapons and ammo. You repair barricades to doors and windows and together you must hold out against waves of ever strengthening opponents! But be careful! As Alma stalks the rooms and streets and if she catches you staring at her, you're in for a terrible time...

All in all I was so pleasantly surprised to know that the F,E,A,R legacy (despite the popular cries) was kept in tact whie Day One Studios added their own interpretation to the series and it worked! F.E.A.R 3 is a more than solid shooter that, for me, is still fun and replayable after already 6 playthroughs. The game is short enough for one playthrough with a buddy, take a lll 10 minute break then go straight back, swapping roles and doing it again which is exactly what me and my girlfriend did! It keeps the campaign lean and eventful, nothing tacked on to try and trick you that your getting you money's worth simply because it was so and so many hours long. The game is fun by itself but ultimately, F.E.A.R 3 is best played with a 'brother'. Whether your experience will be about brotherly love or sibling rivalry will depend on you!

reviewText: Yes, it's true, this game doesn't start new plotlines, it doesn't present new characters and there's no radical change in gameplay if compared to the previous games of the series. And it's great because this game, in fact, is an epilogue and as an epilogue it does an amazing job tying up loose ends and resolving all the matters.\nThis final instalment to the franchise is the perfect conclusion of the outstanding horror story, thrilling and dramatic denouement of the confrontation between the brothers.\nDefinitely worth getting, at least for the priceless opportunity to play as Paxton Fettel.

reviewText:
A F.E.A.R. title without the actual F.E.A.R feeling? Sounds bad, but...Hint: At the end of this review you will find a TL;DR and a video section.

----------------------------------------------------------------

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ REVIEW]▬▬▬▬●
F.E.A.R 3, a first-person shooter and direct sequel to F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin, was developed by Day-1 Studios and released by Warner Bros. in June 2011. Day-1 Studios are known for their previous development of F.E.A.R 1 on the PS3 and XBOX 360. F.E.A.R 3 is also available for Windows, Xbox360 and PS3 and runs on a heavily modified Despair Engine.  Unlike the predecessors, it includes now a Co-Op mode for which the whole game feels to be designed.

9 months after the events from F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin, Alma is in her labour ready to give birth to her third child. Unforseen consequences for the real world, the army tries to prevent this from happening. The game starts off by showing Point Man, the first son from Alma, in a prision somewhere in South America, where he gets violently interrogated. His younger brother, Paxton Fettel, joins the interrogation and helps his brother to escape. Both are now on their way to her mother and encounter heavy resistance. Will they both work hand in hand like brothers or has Paxton Fettel a completely different plan?
The story itself is not that easy to understand, not even for veterans of this series. While many modern shooters have a great lack of deeper story, F.E.A.R. 3 tries to walk the other way around. Complex narration sticks to the whole gameplay and creates even more confusion than to clear it up. Unfortunately, a real F.E.A.R. feeling does not build up here, yet it is strongly recommended to play through the previous main games to understand at least a few parts in F.E.A.R. 3.

But the gameplay compensates, where the story more or less fails. In the old manner of classic arcade shooters, the player has to run and gun through a horde of enemies beginning from humans right up to the worst nightmares from hell. Main elements from the previous games, such as the slow motion ability are carried over and got a small improvement. New in F.E.A.R 3 is the possibility to lean behind walls, pillars and objects by pressing the Q-button. This allows the player to shoot from different angels while having the safety against enemies bullets. Does the player wants to proceed he can either press Q again to leave the hiding place or vault over, if the current object or wall permits it.
New weapons found their way into the game for example the Goliath, Arc Beam and Riot Gear, while already known weapons, like the pistol or shotgun, got again a more futuristic appearance. The Bullet proofed vest is removed and medkits are now exchanged into a so-called bloodscreen, known from Call of Duty and other arcade shooters. The character heals himself over time, as long as enemies do not hit him. Sadly very annoying and not challenging at all, compared to the other both games before.
Highly praised as acting smart in the previous games from this series, the A.I lost a lot of intelligence in F.E.A.R. 3. Enemies still search for cover, but mostly run blind into the line of sight from the player. That makes them an easy target and decreases the difficulty a lot, even when set higher.

The third follow-up offers now the option to choose between two different characters, either the protagonist Point Man or Paxton Fettel, the antagonist. And here is, where the new Co-Op feature comes in. F.E.A.R. 3 quickly makes clear, that it is meant to be played with two people. Depending on who player is the hoster, he plays Point Man in the tried and tested way to gun down everyone who stands in the way. Point Man is also the only one who is able to slow down the time and to use weapons directly. However, the psychic counterpart Paxton Fettel can not use weapons directly but indirectly. His psychic abilities reach from fire blasts of psychic energy out of his hand to possessing human bodies for a limited amount of time if he does not collect enough souls from other killed enemies, what allows him to use weapons.

Graphically, the game can not shine this time. Medicore textures ingame and overall low details disappoint and can not give the player the actual F.E.A.R. feeling, since everything is too much illuminated. Cutscenes are too blurry, but overall surprise with their graphical appearance. Since F.E.A.R 3 is already 5 years old, everything can be forgiveable.
Controlwise, moving around, searching for cover, vaulting over objects and shooting feels very smooth as expected from a modern egoshooter.
The sounds are clean and thrilling, for the weapons as well as the surroundings. The voiceacting is even better than before and makes it perfect to listen to the cutscenes.

In the end F.E.A.R. 3 can not be recommended as an actual follow-up of this series, but for being a very solid egoshooter. Fans of this franchise will be disappointed but if someone is searching for a great egoshooter with unique features, F.E.A.R. 3 offers around 6 hours of a lot of run and gun.

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ RÉSUMÉ]▬▬▬▬●
After I have finished F.E.A.R 1 and 2 with a more or less satisfied feeling, I could not wait to play through the third follow-up as well. With the expectation to continue where F.E.A.R 2 ended I got greatly disappointed. It feels arcadish, does not include any scary moments and has in its gameplay generally not much in common with F.E.A.R 1 and 2, so fans of this franchise - like me - may be disappointed when playing through this game. Yet, after trying the Co-Op mode I really had a lot of fun with this game. Paxton Fettel, is a brilliant playable side character and through his unique telekinesis elements very enjoyable throughout the whole gameplay.

Searching for a solid egoshooter with cool characters? F.E.A.R. 3 is, what you are searching for!

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ TL;DR]▬▬▬▬●
[✔] Very solid egoshooter with unique features
[✔] Two different playable characters in single player
[✔] Co-Op (local/internet) and splitscreen
[✔] Overall improved (but not stunning) graphics and great sounds
[✔] New feature to lean behind walls and objects to shoot from different angels

[✖] A.I. not as intelligent as in previous games
[✖] Medkits and bullet proof vest are exchanged into a bloodscreen
[✖] Story very confusing and overall not important for the game
[✖] No F.E.A.R. feeling, missing thrilling and horrifying atmosphere

●▬▬▬▬▬[➤ MEDIA]▬▬▬▬▬●
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2snpE0Tx0VE

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=654143342

----------------------------------------------------------------

If you liked this review and want to see more from me, give this review a thumbs up! I also appreciate every feedback!

To keep updated about my reviews, feel free to visit Morbs' Review Base and follow the curator page to never miss an review from me!

reviewText:
Summary:

If you are looking for a FPS, buy this.

If you are looking for a F.E.A.R game, don't buy this.


Positive:

-The gameplay mechanics are fluid and crisp.
-Enjoyable combat.
-Graphics are amiable for a modern day game.
-Cheesy lines from enemies. (I like it).
-Will catch you up on the story if you havn't played the first 2 installments (Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate excluded).

Negative:

-The graphics seem a backward step from F.E.A.R 2.
-The story is contradictory and dissapointing.
-It tries to be scary and falls short unlike previous installments.
-Much easier than past 2 installments by taking on a generic health system (I'M LOOKING AT YOU COD), you recover health instead of trying to scavenge it and armour.
-I don't know who thought it would be a good idea to introduce a point based challenge system in order to 'level up'.
-'A lot' of reiteration of previous F.E.A.R story points.
-Do not understand the Replicas' 'deal' this game.
-Alma?

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is an average, and unremarkable, horror first person shooter.  If you have ever played a fps then you'll be familiar will everything that F.E.A.R. 3 has to offer, if you have never played a fps before... well that kind of odd and remarkable, and you probably shouldn't have your first fps experience with F.E.A.R. 3. This isn't to suggest that F.E.A.R. 3 is a bad game, but more to the fact that the game lacks polish.

It has some nice things going for it, the campaign gameplay varies enough to stay fresh, there is co-op (which I didn't get to experience since none of my friends have this game), and the two playable characters feel slightly different from each other.

However, the game has significant things going against it. For starters, it isn't scary, which is a problem, considering that it is a horror fps. Second, the campaign itself drags on for way too long and often feels like it is stretching things out, just to fully use an environment (a la, if we spent months making a haunted department store, then the player is going to see every freaking room in it). And lastly, the game's story is very narrow and straight to the point, so if you haven't played the previous games in the series, you'll not going to understand everything that is going on, and even if you did, you're still not going to understand everything.

If you play this game under ideal conditions (co-op with a good friend that scares easily) then I would image that this game would be great, however, that isn't going to happen for the vast majority of people, so this game is not worth it.

reviewText: Even for an avid fan of the series, this was hard to get through.  The duck-and-cover nature of the engine is poorly suited to the type of game F.E.A.R. is and the execution was good, but it just didn't fit.  Shuffling game studios hurt the franchise more than helped it, and I would much rather play the first game over the second or third.  The story becomes a bit farfetched at this point--even by F.E.A.R. standards--and the map design made chokepoints predictable and the levels tedious to get through.  The alternate play style of Paxton Fettel didn't add much to the game, and definitely not enough to redeem it.

reviewText:
Difficulty: Hard
The Bottom Line: Solid/Great
Score: 8.5

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

The first F.E.A.R. was an outstanding masterpiece. The two following expansion packs were so so.

F.E.A.R 3 features an even smarter AI. The enemy soldiers are quick to take cover, switch positions, retreat, suppress you, throw grenades, flank you and charge you when they can. There's also plenty of enemy chatter that you can hear which allows you to anticipate some of your enemies' movements. They will also call you out if you are hiding for too long.

There's also a horde mode, reminiscent of the Call of Duty Zombie mode. You still build barricades and get better weapons but this time you are fighting the smart AI that is assaulting your position instead of shooting brain dead zombies.

Ultimately there's not that many negatives, as far as the solid gameplay is concerned.

Overall: F.E.A.R. 3 is a solid shooter.

reviewText: F.E.A.R. 3 is nothing like the previous F.E.A.R. games: gone are the horror elements, med-kits, upgrade pick-ups, multiple paths to out flank enemies and intelligent AI. If you're a fan of the F.E.A.R. series it may be worth playing just to see where the confusing and spotty story ends up or if you're looking for a shooter this game has some potential but it's nothing like the previous games which are way superior to this one.

reviewText:
This game focus on coop shooting gameplay, less scary but still creepy sometimes.
Many complaint it is too short, yes. But there are types of game mode available.

GAME MODE:
Campaign (Solo / 2 players Coop)
F**king Run! (Multiplayer escaping mode)
Contractions (Multiplayer round-based survival mode)
Soul Survivor (Multiplayer ghost possess mode)
Soul King (Multiplayer soul collect competition)
RECOMMENDATION?:
*Yes, for who enjoy gun shooting, cover system, scary stuff, ghost, demon, etc
*No, if gamer is still looking for same theme from FEAR 1.

+Good graphic quality (2011 tech)
+Able to play as Paxton Fettel in coop
+Paxton Fettel have power to posses enemy, telekinesis, throw objects & etc
+Very enjoyable for 2 player in coop
+2 type of powerful Mech Suit
+Some creepy places
+Alma doll collection
+Auto-regen heal (not pickup medic kit anymore)
+Complete challenges to raise rank (increase slo-mo meter/possesion meter)

-Alma is not scary
-Day time gun fight (which is not scary)
-Only 2 weapons at a time (doesn't bother me)
-Jin Sun-Kwon is not pretty as in FEAR 1
-The story & ending is not satisfy for me

ENJOYMENT:
*Score for Offline gaming 8/10
*Score for Online gaming 9/10

COMPLETION TIME:
*Main campaign: Around 5 hours
*Main + Extra: Around 9+ hours

MORE INFORMATION:
*IGN review score 8.0/10
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cbWvpeF1Lc0

WORTH BUYING?
*Yes, if you want the developer continue make a good game in future!
*No, if you can wait for 75% sale in future!
*Purchase the FEAR collection pack is more valuable (+all DLC)

reviewText:
And I thought F.E.A.R. 2 was a good game, this one is even better.

After finishing and enjoying F.E.A.R. 2 I got started on playing F.3.A.R. pretty much straightaway and I was at first not as impressed with the game compared to the previous one. Just a couple of silly things like how they changed the combat and removed health packs and armour but I soon got used to using the radial red/blood onscreen to know when to hide and when to push forward into combat. The story with this one was really, really good and the cutscenes were superbly done. I would've said this game was about as good as 2 but no better, that was until I completed the game as Pointman and unlocked Fettel.  Oh boy. Playing as Fettel elevated this game above F.E.A.R. 2 instantly. I played it through to completion again with Fettel and it didn't feel stale in any way because Fettel is just the most ridiculous fun you can have in a game. I can't use any more superlatives and you should probably buy this series of games and enjoy them.

I recommend this game more than I recommended 2 in my review for that. Massive fun on both play throughs but the Fettel one is best. Get this game!

reviewText: This game is absolutely terrible. The devs turned this once awesome horror series into an action oriented co-op shooter.\n\nFirst off the horror" parts in this game are neither creepy nor frightening
date:
they're simply annoying. FEAR and Project Origin did their job far better in this regard. In addition to describe the A.I. as weak in this game would be an understatement. It was a huge step backwards from the previous games.

If you don't play this game in co-op be prepared for very unfair fights. How about fighting a mech with little to no cover or possibilities to avoid damage and your opponent having a huge amount of health and hitting like a truck? Sounds fun doesn't it? (not to me) - The "boss fights" are not really what I'd call challenging as they don't require that much thinking. It's just kill them faster than they can kill you.

The story is just a mess. Characters from the previous games don't make any sense and there are plotholes all over the place.

Finally from what I saw the multiplayer was dead on arrival. There was only these gauntlet like missions and no real player vs player action. But even in these co-op missions you have to compete against your teammates. If you are to slow or not good enough you will be left behind or have a negative influence on the overall performance. I don't know who designed it
recommended: but it wasn't thought out very well."

It tries to spice things up with a first person cover mechanic, but it doesn't add very much in terms of usefulness.  In fact, it's a bit wonky and often times hinders you.  There were several times I was hit while in cover" without being able to see the enemy in front of me.  Fetel's possession and psychic mechanics seemed fun

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is a First Person Horror Shooter.

It continues the story line of F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 but here you are again the protagonist from the first game.
The Point Man, one of Almas childs. And actually you can play 2 characters, the other one being Paxton Fettel, the other son of Alma, but only when you have finished the game once. There are 2 different endings. The first, which is probably the real" ending is the good one of the Point Man and the other one is the Evil end of Paxton Fettel.

The Story itself is easy explained. You have to reach Alma because she is giving birth to her new child.
But this is a hard and stony way especially because you have to escape from a prison first but because both brothers working together it works. Working together more or less. But beside you are hunted by your bad memories of your childhood which feature Harlan Wade
date: the "father" of Alma. Saying father is this case is an insult because he is a real ****
recommended: well you know what I mean. You have to forget your memories of Harlan Wade.\n\nOn your way you pass many levels and especially different ones! No level looks the same and this is actually what was really amazing! Never saw so much variety and nice design in the levels. Pretty much the best from all F.E.A.R. games but this is probably the only aspect thats better compared to other games

reviewText:
This game showed me true horror - because someone incompetent inheriting a great franchise and turning it into... THIS, now that's what I call terror.

Nothing to do with F.E.A.R. series. It's a budget-tier mix of CoD and Painkiller. No atmosphere, no suspense, 2 weapons limit, so corridor-ish it's not even funny. Shooting itself was always a strong point of F.E.A.R., here it feels bland and unsatisfying. There's the autoregen instead of hitpoints, which I could tolerate if this wasn't supposed to be a horror game. Also someone thought it needs some Cool&Hip (tm) pseudo RPG elements, so you gain points for stuff like picking up ammo and recieve bonuses, i.e. a bigger ammo limit.

I really warn you against this game, there are indie shooters much better than this blockbuster"."

reviewText:
So i have beat this on console and bought it on sale to play some of the co-op with my friend when it was 75% off. The co-op is fun but virtually any game that isn’t flat awful or broken is pretty fun with friends. There are two characters with different game play, the series original Point Man and Paxton Fettel. Here are the pros and cons of the PC version.

Pros

- Paxton Fettel is really fun to play as with unique and fun interesting paranormal abilities like possession.
- Has a Co-op campaign
- A nice achievement and upgrade system
- You have a nice set of customizable controls with secondary bindings for all functions
- Nice sound options with multiple sliders

Cons

- Simple console like FPS cover based shooting. Press Q then arrows to pop out from cover shoot use bullet time to change cover repeat
- Instead of mildly tactical squad based combat you push through a crowed, fight a hoard, push through crowd again.
- Fairly linear with much less alternative routes then the two predecessors
- The bullet time for point man is essentially useless and just thrown in because it is part of the series
- Not a great port with some bad low res textures and limited graphics options
- Super unbalanced Riot shield, find it, win
- for the price a little too short. Took me almost 7 hours on console to beat
- Multiplayer is pretty much dead and was tacked on anyway
- Simple contrived plot

- Adds nothing to the story of the franchise and in fact is kind of an insult to fans not that the other two had great ones, but it doesn’t fit into the universe (if you don’t care about story like me though that doesn’t matter much)
- Horrible main character ,rugged, scruffy, boring, robotic, bad ♥♥♥, action hero template number 4 instead of the silent protagonist (again you can get past that easily but if that stuff matters to you it will probably disappoint)

My verdict

Generic and not worth your time; It is another drop in the sea of mediocrity. Play F.E.A.R or F.E.A.R 2 instead, they are both much better games in every aspect. Unless you get it on a good sale to mess around with as Paxton Fettel it isn’t worth your time or money.

reviewText:
If you are the type of person that doesn’t like to read a long review, then I will provide you with a short description which properly conveys the message of my full-review.

DON’T BUY THIS GAME expecting the same type of game play as the previous F.E.A.R installments. HOWEVER IF YOU LIKE THROWING AWAY MONEY AND PLAYING A BADLY PORTED COD STYLE FPS FOR P_SSIES THAT LIKE TO HIDE BEHIND COVER 90% OF THE TIME I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT.

OK, now that this is said, I shall begin with my full-review of the game.

First off, I would like to point out that I have played both F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R 2 and had a blast of a time while playing them. I really loved the style of the games, and I would say that F.E.A.R. 1 is the best out of the entire series.

Now onto F.E.A.R 3 …
The game starts with some nice cut-scenes that manage to get me all hyped up to play another F.E.A.R.  game. As soon as these cut-scenes end I get the mission to escape from a prison. At that point I could already tell that the game has a different feel to it, like it wasn’t as dark as the previous games.  But I didn’t care about that and continue playing. So after walking out of my prison cell the game starts explaining the controls and after killing a guard I get my first gun.  Now I am ready to once again become a bad 4ss MOF0 and bust some caps, or so I thought…

NOPE NOPE NOPE.jpeg; As soon as the action starts and I end up in my first shootout the game explains that you need to use
Q to hide.  Now.. hiding isn’t that bad I mean it’s logical to hide to avoid ending up like Swiss cheese.  But this game brings it to a whole new level, the being a little p_ssy level.  The map is obviously designed so you have to hide behind every other f_cking box. And as soon as you get shot, you lose an unknown amount of health and you can simply regenerate it by hiding for 5 f_cking seconds.

So where is the challenge to managing your health by using the med kits like in the previous games?  And why are we hiding all the f_cking time, point man used to be a bad 4ss.

OK this is also the moment I start to feel like the game wasn’t developed for the PC and is actually a cheap port. So even with all of that going on I continue my escape from prison whilst encountering several shootouts and getting annoyed about the whole continuously hiding behind boxes and having the unnatural feeling of playing a bad port.  This goes on for a while and I finally decide that this game is a piece of sh!t.. and I got better games to play.

So how did the fear series end up with this piece of sh!t? It’s because this game wasn’t even developed by the same company that developed the initial fear games.  NOPE not developed by Monolith but by Day 1 Studios.

Anyhow thank the seven gods that I bought this game in a steam sale and did not have to pay full price. Because after just about 15 minutes of play time I decided it was a piece of sh_t and uninstalled the game. And I didn’t even get to die once.. So I guess you are practically immortal in this game as long as you hide behind boxes.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is a FPS game that has more action and less horror than the previous F.E.A.R. games.

The main campaign can be played solo or co-op and you can choose between 2 different characters, each with their own unique abilities.

The main campaign is pretty short (less than 10 hours), but you can replay it as a different character. There are also additional Co-op and VS modes that can add hours of gameplay.

Overall, I give F.E.A.R. 3 a rating of 7.5/10.

reviewText:
I loved the first two games in the F.E.A.R. franchise. I loved the insane action, slow-motion roundhouse kicks and bodies exploding into Jell-O(tm) when you pumped a shell into them. I loved the freaky-deaky story, the mysterious protagonist(s) and the occasional flirt with enigmatic storytelling, the screeching, violin-falling-down-the-stairs soundtrack that worked in all its beautiful discordance and hair-raising abruptness. The scripted scares wove ladders, hallways, doors and windows into shockingly intricate little spookouts that contrasted with the bombastic shootouts that framed them, and it all just worked out so WELL. Hell, even the ending of the second game was pretty good in my eyes.

And then this game. Oh boy.

I hardly know what to say about it, and I hardly have the energy- even now- to summon a full-blown rant on this marvelous marvelous deconstruction of a once-great shooter franchise. The scares? Gone. The lonesome eeriness? Gone. Hope you like playing co-operatively with your psychic *** brother who has lost all of his charm now that you can see how he works and he's always trotting along beside you like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ doberman. The Half-Life-esque presentation that kept you in the protagonist's perspective constantly and almost never thrust you into immersion-punching cutscenes? Hope you didn't like them, because apparently neither did WB. Did I mention that this game isn't scary?
It gets most of the action from previous titles right, but it's more than just lacking in the horror department. The game called... CALLED... 'Fear'? It doesn't even try to be scary. At all.

reviewText:
Short but fun coop FPS with horror elements, great controls and some minor flaws
What is very important with regard to the third episode of the F.E.A.R. universe is actually that you should not fall for a direct comparison to previous titles. The present episode builds on and has its strong points when it comes to the coop element.

Concerning storyline, concerning horror / scary moments, it might let you down or even disappoint hardcore F.E.A.R. fans. Take the game as it comes. Take it as a storydriven two-player coop FPS.

A rare genre actually and what makes F.E.A.R. 3 definitely an enrichment in your library.

What I liked
Story driven coop FPS
Great, direct controls, good input feeling, good weapon handling
Two different playstyles which complement each other
End bosses and mech gameplay
Graphics are good and serve the purpose; very fluid performance
Some nice gore effects
F.E.A.R. universe / story is brought further
Coop horde survival mode
Level-up system
Plenty of achievements
Replay value together with a friend
What I didn't like
It is short (5 to 6 hours) and gameplay feels a bit repetitive
It might get boring in a pure solo party
Blurry cutscenes which do not justice to a sharp display
Repetitive enemies
Horror effects are not scary enough for F.E.A.R.
Annoying connection issues with Steam
Dead multiplayer, so organize yourself well in order to play coop (neutral)
No 3D vision support. It has been abandonned im comparison to previous titles, which is a huge let down for fans of VR.
It is overall a great coop experience. If you play merely solo, I would say there are plenty of better FPS. If you like the F.E.A.R. universe, do not get too much disappointed that the game is not that scary. But it complements well the storyline. Grab it together with a friend and have some hours of fun.

reviewText: Just beat F.E.A.R. 3, making me beat every single F.E.A.R. game, okay review time, this game, while not bad, was good in aspects and bad at everything else. let alone, as a fan of the series, this game was kinda a let down too me. I enjoyed the fast pace combat, but it took out all stragity that made the first and second games a hard deal, you actual had to plan out your combat route, know when to use slow-mo, and keep ur wits on guard, Playing as paxton can be pretty fun aswell, as it's a diffrent kinda play to the Series. slo-mo in F.E.A.R. 3 had sometimes almost no propose because by time u use it, its gone already, F.E.A.R. 3 compared to the others had minimum to no horror aspect, no dark atmosphere, and quite frankly, the story line was poor and kinda boring. they tried to escalate the matter of the situation, without telling us why it's happening. Taking out the replica forces made NO sense to me, and they never Evan explain why there not there, i mean they were in 2, and still being controlled, so why not in 3, and why the ♥♥♥♥ is point man in captivity when at the end of F.E.A.R. 1 he escaped with his team. F.E.A.R. 3 has beautiful graphics, smooth game play, brutal combat, and an interesting Ranking system. As for story line, atmosphere, tone, and excitability, it was a huge let down, i have to say by far F.E.A.R. 2 was the best in the series. F.E.A.R. 3 just feels more like call of duty when it trys to be creepy. this is a great stand alone game, esp for FPS fans, but for personal fans of the F.E.A.R. Series as a whole, this is just a disappointment. hopefully, if they make another game, they will try to make it less Call of dutyish" and return to the Dark

reviewText:
At first you think this game is an all-round progression from FEAR 2. Everything seems mechanically better, graphics and realism have both stepped up a notch. It soon becomes apparent, though,  that the story really is getting old - it just lacks mystery and suspense.

To make matters worse, the game seems to have completely missed the mark on the horror side. It tries to scare, but just doesn't. Towards the end of the game you start to get tired of boring story sequences interrupting the action!

So what are you left with? Well, a good urban warfare shooter, albeit a little short.  It still comes highly recommended, but I'm afraid that if you have expectations for this game being a horror"
date: you will feel let down. It's still one of the few true coop games around
recommended: and the coop is a great deal of fun

reviewText: I got this on HumbleBundle. This is a fun horror THEMED shooter. I say themed cause it's just a shooter with some ghost and erie music. All be it a good horror themed shooter. The gunplay was amazing everygun sounded the way it should. Descent challege and some badass guns. The graphics are descent colors are what you exspect from a horror shooter. This is not for you hardcore Survival horror shooters fans. Get the 1st fear or DOOM 3. The story is well.. Nothing really. reviewText:
I have always been an avid fan of the FEAR franchise. Fear 3 is the 3rd and probably most unique installment of this franchise. I am wondering if this should be considered the last one or WB is planning to publish another episode sometime in the near future.

In Fear 2 we skipped the story of the good old Point Man, our protagonist from the 1st episode, and now we pick up his tale from where we were left off. Paxton also returns and this gives a game a unique experience as coop campaign is now available. Paxton can jump into enemies and take over them for a short period of time. On his own he is rather weak but once you possess a soldier you can use his weapons and should you be eliminated you can quickly find another host.

Sequences with the Mech also return and they are more devastating than ever. There are more monsters now so it seems the developers upped the horror-like nature of the game a bit. Single player is relatively long and with the 2nd protagonist (Paxton) you have replayability here which is good news.

The field where Fear 3 really shines is multiplayer. There are various game modes out there that are interesting and challenging, too. In F**king Run, for example, you are running away from a wall that means instant death once it reaches you. While running away you also need to eliminate the oncoming waves of enemies and cooperation is a must as if anybody from your team is caught by the wall that's game over for the entire group.

I liked Fear 3. For me the best is the 2nd episode in this trilogy but the 3rd installment also offered an exciting action-horror experience and while I do not really favour the approach of releasing more and more sequels for a game I would be delighted to play a possible 4th episode.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is a decent game on its own, but unfortunately I can't recommend it to anyone because the experience alone doesn't quite cut it like the first installment.

The core gameplay design is based around cooperative play with a partner, however due to non-existent player base, it's almost impossible to play this game online. The campaign is very short and can be finished in less than 4 hours. Unlike the first installment, this game is not worth buying just for solo experience.

Even if you do manage to find someone to play with, you would probably experience a lot of problems (like lag and desync) which stem from bad netcode and unoptimized load management.

The only good thing about this game is its sophisticated A.I. which honestly, is one of the best I've played against. But again, it was the same case with F.E.A.R. 1 as well.

Other than that, level design is uninspiring and story is boring. If you're looking for about 4 hours of solo content, go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, buy the first installment. F.E.A.R. 1 is one of the best games ever made.

reviewText:
Every time I see FEAR 3 on sale I see people bashing it as the worst in the series, but the meta score is actually not too bad 74/100. Unlike the first 2 FEAR games, FEAR 3 has one of those regenerating health systems where you just hide under cover for a few seconds and you recover back to full health. No need to scrounge for med kits or armor. Also, the game seems built around 2 player co-op, which I like in first person shooter games (when I have someone to play with).

*Spoilers ahead*
FEAR 3 takes place an unspecified amount of time after the events of FEAR 2. Alma is pregnant and getting ready to give birth, as a result her psychic power is tearing up the city (possibly the world). Again the main opposition is the private military contractor Armacham, who seems to have become 100x more powerful than they were in the first games. Even without their clone super soldiers from the first games, Armacham seems capable of overrunning and occupying entire cities with soldiers, aircraft, and power armor. You play the Point Man protagonist from the first FEAR game (the guy you play in FEAR 2 also shows up briefly) but this time you have an “imaginary” friend Paxton Fettel (Bad guy from the first game). Your primary goal this time around is to reach Alma before she gives birth and deal with her once and for all. Unfortunately for you, Alma’s psychic pain has summoned nightmare creatures and twisted the surviving civilian population into crazed psychos.

Unlike the previous FEAR games, FEAR 3 is broken down into missions or “levels” with each mission giving you a point score at the end. You gain points by finding collectables, killing enemies, and completing “challenges.” The challenges are similar to the “Skill shots” in Bulletstorm, where it’s basically just using various methods of killing. For example, 2000 points for killing enemies with a specific weapon, or 1000 points for getting 25 headshots, or 2000 points for getting 3 backstabs. The points aren’t just for show, by the way. You “level up” when you gain enough points and each level gives you some kind of perk, such as +10% health or +bullet capacity. You can replay levels as many times as you want to “grind” for points. This means that the game will get easier over time as you replay it. You might notice that when you first start the game, it seems far more difficult than the previous ones, well this changes as you level up and get stronger. The regenerating health means you can charge groups of enemies and just duck for cover when your screen is almost completely red (near death). Healing is free unlike FEAR 1 and 2 which had limited med kits.

As I mentioned earlier, the game is built with 2 player co-op in mind. At the end of each mission there is a ranking between the 2 players to see who scored highest in several categories. The game’s ending depends on which of the two characters “won” the most missions. Of course if you’re playing single player the character you’re playing (Fettel or Point Man) will “win” every level you complete. Point Man’s gameplay is the same as the previous games (standard shooter with Slow-Mo power), But Fettel is a psychic commander. This means he can possess enemies and use them to fight (he doesn’t have slow-mo). Every time he takes over a new body he gets the weapons of the possessed enemy, so you can’t hoard powerful weapons or grenades the way Point Man does. You can only hold 2 weapons now, unlike 3 weapons in FEAR 1 and 4 weapons in FEAR 2. Possession also means you won’t be able to use the awesome power armors because the possessed body won’t last long enough.

Pros:
+Excellent graphics and visuals. Large variety of weapons available.
+Some cool new enemies, particular the Phase Commander and Phase Caster.
+A lot of replay value. I just finished the game and immediately restarted as Fettel.
+2 player co-op available. Also a bunch of various multiplayer game modes I haven’t tried.

Cons:
-The game is very short, about 6 hours to beat the first time. Replay is strongly encouraged though.
-The story is weaker than the first FEAR games. There’re a lot of unnecessary “dream sequences” that don’t seem to add much. You just walk forward about 15 seconds with someone talking in voice over and it ends.
-I get the feeling that the enemies are much “dumber” than FEAR 1 enemies. They tend to stick behind the same piece of cover and just pop their heads out to shoot from there.

Overall I think the game is well worth playing for fans of First Person Shooters and people who want to see how the FEAR story ends. Once you finish a mission in single player, the Fettel character is unlocked so you can try playing him for that particular level. The way to see the Fettel game ending is by playing through the game a second time (or play the game in co-op and Fettel has the highest score every mission). One thing I noticed is that the game’s Steam achievements seem to be half for multiplayer, and not many people are playing the multiplayer. This isn’t surprising since the game has been out for a few years. I’ll probably only be able to get about 45% completion for the game achievements by myself.

reviewText: What to say about this game... it's pretty and all that, but it's rather disappointing. It's nowhere near as memorable as the previous game in the series. The campaign story is confusing and uninteresting. Scary events aren't really scary. There's co-op mode around this time though, which helps. There's also four different multiplayer modes, which I haven't played much, but they feel slapped on. I'd say they are okay, but nothing more. I'm not sure what else to say. Not a particularly good game, but an ok co-op shooter. I'm leaning more towards the negative side than the positive side, so it's a thumbs down from me. Consider getting it if it's cheap.

reviewText:
About The Games:
The F.E.A.R franchise has always been & always will be a game about The Paranormal" expect a lot of Ghosts in each of the games more so in F.E.A.R 1 & 2. That generally has a solid story line and to be expected in a game about the paranormal plenty of gore & jump scares THESE ARE NOT BAD THINGS!

F.E.A.R had you playing in the shoes of an unknown solider for the "First Encounter Assault Recon Team" or F.E.A.R for short
date: you went in and you were tasked to capture a test subject who was designed to control these "Super Soldiers" for a war. The project was a success except things went wrong & the leader went nutso & so you're here to clean up the mess.\n\nF.E.A.R 2 had you playing the role of another solider for the "First Encounter Assault Recon" who was in another squad & was deployed just before the ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan in the first game
recommended: you were tasked to find & capture a doctor who was working on the test subject & then you are to eliminate the test subject & attempt to shut down project Origin by eliminate the main "Ghost" who was causing all the mayhem around the city
hoursPlayed:
unfortunatly things don't pan out so well & then ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan & of course once more you're trying to battle your way out of the storm.

F.E.A.R 3 on the other hand has you go back into the shoes of the "Unknown Soldier" from F.E.A.R 1 along with the ghost of your brother Paxton Fettle who was the test subject they were developing to control the "Super Soldiers" & use it for the war. The story fell really flat here & it certainly wasn't as much of an enjoyable game as the first 2 were.

The Review:
F.E.A.R 3 offers VERY minimal satisfaction for returning fans of the original games or for Single Player gamers as it's lost everything that made the first 2 F.E.A.R games great & on edge spooky

reviewText: I always heard bad things about F.E.A.R. 3 and the first few hours of me playing it gave me all I need to make my own opinion about the game. If you're a fan of the original F.E.A.R. you turn back right now, otherwise you'll most likely loose your admiration for this franchise. To be honest I didn't really liked F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin as much as I liked the first F.E.A.R. game and it's expansions, it did have the F.E.A.R. feel to it but for me it wasn't as good as the original. But now, F.E.A.R. 3 is where they've messed up everything, everything I liked about the previous games was gone. First, there's no medkits or reflex boosts on the game because you now have regenerating health and you unlock levels, and yes I do mean actual ingame levels, by scoring points, I feel like they tried making F.E.A.R. 3 a kinda of score attack game but making it similar to modern first person shooters. So, if there's no medkits and reflex boosts there's not that much of incentive to go through each level exploring and trying to find hidden stuff to make your life easier... but then again they've changed that, most of the hidden stuff that you can now find in F.E.A.R. 3 are corpses which you can connect to" and gain points by doing so and also finding some weird little statues that I also believe that give you points. Everytime you level up you can gain an increase to HP
date: increased time that you can use your slow time and increased ammo for each gun. I pretty much hate when developers nowadays make first person shooters with regenerating health because that basicly just means that everytime you're on low health you just need to get behind a wall and wait for your health to regenerate which I find to be somewhat
recommended: dumb. And now the guns. I thought that the shooting from F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin was easier than the original F.E.A.R. but hell did they make it Call of Duty style on F.E.A.R. 3

reviewText: F.3.A.R. An interesting concept gone completely horribly wrong. Following some what the events of F.E.A.R. 2 you can play as either the Point Man or Paxton Fettel, making for an interesting Co-Op experience compared to recent titles. The game play can be quite entertaining, however offering very little replay value. Also the story writing goes further down the trash bin, personally letting me down as I am a die hard fan of the original F.E.A.R. and admittedly enjoyed F.E.A.R. 2. However taking a thriller/shooter and casualizing the game play to CoD style truly took the games identity away. I have lost all hope of this game coming back to its original stature. Do NOT purchase this title, do not recommend. Also looking at the banners for each title should show how the quality was given up each title to where it stands today.

reviewText: As a fan of the first two FEAR games, I was pretty disappointed with how this game turned out. It gave up a lot of the interesting design of the first two for a rather bland, run-of-the-mill first person shooter experience. Levels were reduced to little more than straight corridors with things to hide behind and seemed to drag on longer than they should have as enemies filled choke points. Most of the guns felt uninspired compaired to guns from the first two and the weapon limit (brought over from 2, which was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ part of that game) didnt help at all. The worst part though is the wasted opportunity of a second playable character in the form of Paxton Fettel. So many more interesting gameplay mechanics could have been introduced in his powers, but we only got a stun blast attack and the ability to posses someone, which is basically just like playing as Point Man. I only really played this to see the conclusion of the story, which wasn't that great really, so I cant really recommend this on any level. (single player wise anyway, never tried the multiplayer).

F.E.A.R. 3, basically, is a great game for acheivement hunters since many of them are fun and not too challenging.

reviewText: This game is quite possibly one of the worst games I have ever played. Even Colonial Marines was more fun than this. I'm doing Coop and so far my experience has been having a completly useless ghost partner that for about 45 seconds can do stuff and me stuck killing everything else. Now this would be fun if the ai weren't shooting hitscan projectiles with pinpoint accuracy with an incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cover system and terrible controls. Ontop of if the AI is literally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the only reason the game is slightly hard is the hitscan. You can grab a riot shield and just melee the base commanders (a super strong boss that is super original totally not just another human with a blue shield) and take literally zero damage and just click for 45 seconds. I killed 4 like that and that was probably the most fun I had in the game was how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and broken it was. Hell I'm writing this because the game has given me Vietnam style flashbacks of horrible Voice Acting, game play, level desing and bugs. So my useless ghost friend as we walk across a huge interstate above the ocean is battle mechs that blow up but oh wait if you get out of them they get full health instantly and don't actually blow up, he got out to revive me and got stuck in a wall forcing us to fight 2 helicopters for 5 minutes again in a fight that takes zero skill since you just hop out and get full health again. This game is pure ♥♥♥♥ and anyone that disagrees has even worse tastes in Video Games than people that liked COD Ghost. The fact that Colonial Marines is better than this ♥♥♥♥ is just sad. Oh and literally none of the game was scary it was just horrifically unfun, unchallenging and a waste of 5$. Oh I also forgot it has cool interactions like opening doors or pushing through revolving doors all the ♥♥♥♥ing time to slow down the game play even more.

reviewText:
[Edit]
We managed to find solution to the coop issue. It seems that you and host needs to stay idle for a while in lobby and in beginning of the game in order to avoid being disconnected all of sudden. We spent 5 minutes talking at lobby and 5 minutes just standing at the beginning of a level. When we finally started to play, we managed to play several levels forward without any issues.

Pros:
* Coop was fun (when it works) and adds a lot to the game.

* Possessing enemies were super fun. Friend in a bad spot? Posess an enemy from behind the enemy line and backstab everyone.

Cons:
* Scoring system sucks. Fettel will always lead in scores in normal game play (shared psychic links). Game endings are also tied to the score system. Should one of the brothers have more points than the other, it will cause good or bad ending.

* The game is not scary. Game does not follow the original fear at all.

* Controls are.. awkward. The game tries to have contextual controls, but fails in it. For example I need own keys for shooting while on feet or in vehicle.

* The game has this typical AAA-game feeling. There is just no depth to it. There is no love for this game.


I'm not going to change my rating for this game. We wasted too much time on the problems and it left a bad taste in mouth.

[Original]
I'm going to give thumbs down, as I was really looking to play this as a coop/multiplayer game.

Buy only for the single player experience. The coop and multiplayer modes disconnect frequently from the host or kicks clients, hosting or not. Tried with multiple hosts with each having an excellent internet connection speeds. All required ports open. With and without a firewall. It just does not work.

A real shame. The game is interesting, controls are working, the game is responsive, but everything is ruined by frequent disconnect issue.

reviewText:
Okay, I am going to get right into this and say that F.E.A.R. 3 is a BAD game, but it is only a BAD game to people who have played the other games. If you've played the other F.E.A.R. games, you understand why this game is the bane of our existance, but, if not, I shall explain it to you.

Alright, F.E.A.R. and F.E.A.R. 2: Project origin were both made by the same company and in the same style. They had large maps that you could get lost in and unnerving environments. Monolith was NOT afraid to hit you with a scare that comes across as mild, though is nothing compaired to the rest of the game, but it get's you anyway, probably even more than the really big scares. It was the small things that kept people on edge for the duration of your play time. The characters were well thought out and they were in no way scared to be brutal. They slapped you with a psychic canibal clone commander from the start who blew through innocent men and woman to get to the people who tortured and killed his mother who was forced into carrying to children via clone fetus implant. Yeah... Pretty sick stuff.

The Problem with F.E.A.R. 3, however, was, not only the fact that the developer who made it KNOWS NOTHING ABOUT HORROR, but also the fact that it was so pointless and soul-crushing that it totally went in the OPPOSITE DIRECTION of what the original creators wanted. Day 1 RUINED F.E.A.R. by turning it into a light, CHEAP, co-op, FPS hell. They almost entirely removed the horror aspect of the game and handed us one of the biggest loads of trash. The problems are as follows.

1. Going by the story line of the previous games, the ending was anti-climactic and a serious let down.

2. The horror aspect it an attempt to use wierd sounds and over-cooked map textures to scare people as well as cheap jumpscares that would hardly startle a small infant.

3. They changed the characters to a fault. The two biggest examples being the Characters Paxton Fettel and Point Man. Paxton had always been propper and rightfully creepy simply by the way he delivered his lines and their context. He now speaks in partial slang and comes across more annoying with his lines than his former eree. Point Man was originally personality-less, intended to be that way by the company that was implimenting his make-shift powers. They didn't want him to have a personality. This also helped the immersion of the game by allowing the player to impliment themselves onto the character. NOW, Point Man has a very angry and cliche silent-protagonist role, comming across as an overused-badass" steriotype.

4. CUTSCENES. The other games had little to no cutscenes. What few they had were all in first person and allowed the player some range of head movement. In F.E.A.R. 3

reviewText: While it fails to compare to the beautifully-crafted original, FEAR 3 is probably one of the most solid built shooters of this year. If you're looking for a game that'll treat you to a night of explosions, bloodshed and pretty-looking rifles, FEAR 3 should definately be considered your mate, especially if you've got a mate of your own to bring along with the cooperative experience it provides.\n\nOf course, I heartfully recommend trying out the first FEAR before you even think of touching this one. The original was a masterpiece of thrills and suspence second only to Half-life, and should be a part of your virtual or physical library if it isn't already.

reviewText:
I'm honestly surprised by how much I enjoyed this considering I'm a hardcore fan of the previous games. I would lie if I said it wasn't fun, alone or with a friend.

This isn't what previous games in the franchise were, this isn't a horror game and it isn't as nearly as tactical as the previous games, but and this is a bit but, I had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of fun. If this game simply wasn't called FEAR I can assure you it would have been received with much more positive reviews.

I grew up with FPS games like FEAR, Half Life, Doom, Quake etc., I love corridor-ish FPS games, I don't mind them being linear, sure it's nice when they have more open levels and more than one approach to a given situation, but I don't really mind linearity as long as the gameplay is good. I love running forward and shooting stuff in games, sure it would have been nice to a true successor to FEAR, but I'm not going to let my fanboism be in the way of me enjoying this.

PROS
*Fun gunplay
*Great with friends
*Bloody and gory as hell
*Action feels satisfying
*Not scary, but definitely atmospheric
*Two characters to play, very different too
*The whole campaign can be played in co-op and in addition there are some bonus game modes
*Visually appealing and should run even on weaker systems
*Contrary to what most people say I found the AI to be pretty alright

CONS
*For the most part linear (doesn't bother me)
*Not that scary
*Story went to ♥♥♥♥
*CGI cutscenes are baaaaad
*Voice acting is questionable
*Can get repetitive if you play alone
*The occasional invisible wall
EDIT:
*Ending is ♥♥♥♥
*Really anticlimactic final interval

I had fun guys, I love FPS games, I didn't mind what most people dislike and both me and my friend had a lot of fun, we plan on finishing this together. It is not a bad game, on the contrary, a lot of fun if you get over the fact it isn't a true FEAR game.

reviewText:
BEFORE i start, like F.E.A.R. 2 THIS one still miss the typical FEAR feeling from the first game...

BUT that doesnt make the game bad (even when the story is not THIS totaly awesome) Play as Pointman or as Fettle both of them have his own gameplay, Gunfight and SlowMo action with Pointman or Prey hunting superpowers with Fettle. (like in every F.E.A.R. the gun play is STILL AMAZING)

But now to the best part... the COOP mode, maybe the BEST COOP GAME you can find (2 Player coop). Fight together or against each other (yeah while coop campaing). You can protect each other (no really Fettle can shield damage from Pointman) or share SlowMo and other powers, or go for score hunting and see who of you two are better and who got the ending.

Only Played Multiplayer solo until now, but what i see i LIKED, even survival did F.E.A.R. 3 GREAT, better as many other games.

Maybe not F.E.A.R. as we know it, but EVERY SINGLE MONEY WORTH.

reviewText: While as a solo experience, it's just a disappointing followup to the previous games in the series, the inclusion of a second playable coop character with unique powers elevates it to a worthwhile use of your time. It's not especially interesting or polished, but the mechanics of the two player characters together makes it an enjoyable campaign to go through with a friend. It also tends to go on sale for very cheap, so if you're looking for a more coop stuff and have a friend to play with, you could do worse. Not my highest recommendation, but I had a good time playing as a ghost who can possess enemies and use their guns against them, because of course I did.

reviewText: It's a shame FEAR 3 didn't sell. But I understand why. I'm a huge fan of the original FEAR developed by Monolith Productions, but its expansion packs developed by Timegate were not very good. Then FEAR 2 was lackluster, and Monolith made that one themselves! When FEAR 3 was announced as a Day One Studios title, we all sort of wrote it off. But it's the best pure FPS of 2011.\n\nPart 1 opted for J-Horror stylings. FEAR 3 doesn't attempt to be scary and fail. It just doesn't attempt. This is fine, because the thing I like about FEAR was its gunplay. The guns, the quite competent enemy squad AI, the slow motion effects. FEAR 3 brings this all back to form (2 felt a bit too console-y") with two additions. The cover system is thankfully quite non-intrusive and doesn't reduce the game to "whack-a-mole" a la Gears of War. Co-op play is where it's at. In fact
date: the game is built for it. Don't play any other way or you may find it impossible. Note: the 2nd player has slightly superior powers."

reviewText: В игре мы играем за Пойтмена, заключенного в тюрьму. Играть за Феттела можно будет после прохождения игры. Он – призрак, имеющий телепатические способности. В многопользовательской игре несколько режимов. В Soul Survivor один из игроков становится призраком. В режиме Soul King все игроки – призраки, вселяющиеся в NPC. Режим Contractions –  это кооперативный мультиплеер с нарастающими волнами противников. В режиме F**king Run четыре человека обороняются от противников. В кооперативе от набранного количества очков зависит концовка игры. Моя оценка 8/10.
