reviewText: В игре мы играем за Пойтмена, заключенного в тюрьму. Играть за Феттела можно будет после прохождения игры. Он – призрак, имеющий телепатические способности. В многопользовательской игре несколько режимов. В Soul Survivor один из игроков становится призраком. В режиме Soul King все игроки – призраки, вселяющиеся в NPC. Режим Contractions –  это кооперативный мультиплеер с нарастающими волнами противников. В режиме F**king Run четыре человека обороняются от противников. В кооперативе от набранного количества очков зависит концовка игры. Моя оценка 8/10.

reviewerDisplayName: Don't let your dreams be dreams
reviewText:
The third chapter of this game is a bit disappointing but it has its good points....only for the fans of the FEAR series...

Classic FPS, shoot at everything you see and, if you don't know FEAR yet...welll...expect a total horror movie style gameplay (with creepy sounds, messy dark hud in some situations, monsters spawning from nowhere etc...).

The story is connected to the previous two chapters of the game; but this time Fettel and Point Man will be friends and they will cooperate to fight Alma....or well....at least they will try to cooperate....

Gameplay, as you expect, is the usual AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - and so on. There aren't too many secrets or loots to find. So it's pretty pretty linear.

Graphic is good with some good effects, but let's be honest...for the scenarios sometimes the textures could be better...even if the final result is still pretty cool

Nice arsenal of weapon to use but....they really satisfy us?...

The gore level, as you expect from a game like FEAR, is really really high. You will easly see ripped body parts flying all over your screen...but....not everyone likes that...

The longevity....well....that's a huge no no no....even if we play at the highest difficulty the game will still be too much easy and too much short. Ok if we finish the game with Point Man (the only character we can use in single player the first time) we will unlock Fettel. So we can play the game again as Fettel with a total different combat system (Point Man is a soldier...Fettel is an undead man with psychicl powers...yes fun to use but...is that enough?),

So what's the good point if we like the FEAR series?
The coop indeed! Ok this will make the game even more shorter (two peeps is better than one alone...) but at least you will always have a bit of fun because as always, playing togheter is better than playing alone.

So if you are a FEAR fan and you have a friend (or a girlfriend/boyfriend) to play with....go ahead and buy the game!

If you are looking for a good co-op game and you are not into FEAR...well....skip this game...there is better out there!

Overall:

Graphic 6/10
Sounds 8/10
Gameplay 6/10
Longevity 4/10
Fun 5/10 (alone) 7/10 (Co-op)

reviewText: On the whole Fear 3 single player mode is about 7/10. But  Co-op in this game was suprisingly enjoyable.  The powers available between the 2 characters make for a diffrent gameplay experience, which adds a unique flavor to the fps genre.  There is also a simple but satifying acheivement based level up system.  This is one game that does achievments and  hidden items damn near perfectly, mostly 'cause it always give you points towards increasing your chracters abilities.  Add in interesting if convluted story (Fear 2:( ), great atmosphere and a minor competetive element and this is one of the best coop experiences of the year.\nGrab a friend and play 9/10 (co-op)

reviewText:
Fear 3...

Fear 1 was scary because you never knew what to expect... Fear 2 was boring I found, fear online was top fun back in the day when it was made and since dead..... Now fear 3...

Graphics: The graphics are decent for the game, not really specialy or amazing or graphic pushing (Which fear one was at the time) It's just a game....

Audio: The game has some creepy sounds, most of the sound is basic fear screams, atmosphere, guns and thats about it.

Controls: The contols are just as easy and simple as the other gears, with some add motions of the way you run and stuff, very easy to get used too.

Game: The game itself is just another FEAR game, but this time for some unknown reason no longer scary or freaky to play, but they have added an amazing coop mode to play with people, some robotos and a few others things (Not going to say or it's a spoiler) into the game which makes the game a lot of fun to play.
The coop is shooter and evil guy, side by side and both helping each other to get through certain sections of the map and really the game is so much more fun because of this...

I did not bother much with the mutlplayer aspect of the game, running around fighting players online.  I gave it a go but that was it and never touched it.

reviewText:
Let’s start off by saying that this isn’t a FEAR game in the same sense as the last two. This is more of an action game with some suspense but lacking the same atmosphere of the previous titles. Same as Dead Space 3 that way.

That being said this is a very enjoyable and action packed shooter. The game offers a great deal of diversity when it comes to levels, the enemy types are not so diverse but still enjoyable to fight against. The world itself is the same as the previous games so I had a great time just looking around at the psychic cataclysms that was Fairpoint.

The characters were the same as the first game, one brother insane the other silent but that didn’t detract. The story was fairly good and I did want to see what happened at the end, it does follow on from the second one so I’d recommend playing that one first unless you just want action then this one is the best bet.

I liked this game a lot, it was not what I was expecting but it was great none the less. Plus if you replay it you can be Fettel and have a great time making people explode with your mind. There are also a lot of multiplayer modes available, I didn’t try them but they did look like good fun.

Over all I recommend this if it’s on sale and you like action and a little horror.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
Full disclosure. I played this game before playing F.E.A.R. 1, it's DLC's or 2, and while I do recommend it, there are several large caveats and it's a tentative recommendation.

Pros:
- Looks pretty good, nothing extraordinary though
- Co-op is fun
- Multiplayer is pretty alright
- Story was fairly interesting to me, if rather cliched. But perhaps it only interested me because I had no idea what was going on....ever.
- Gameplay is ok
- Multiple endings

Cons:
- 5 hours long, I was bloody awful at it and my co-op partner carried us, we respawned a LOT and it still only took us about 5 and a half hours.
- Extremely linear, linearity isn't bad but Fear 3's linearity is similar to being on rails
- Co-op gameplay is lopsided. Pointman's gameplay is well worn and honestly sort of boring but much easier, or Paxton, who has gameplay that's more fun yet not nearly as solid, it's much easier to do well in the grading system each mission insists on as Pointman as opposed to Paxton
- Not horror, like not even a little.
- MP servers are dead in the water
- Repetitive gameplay
- Questionable AI(at times)
- Just mediocre, neither the graphics, nor the story, nor the non-existent horror help this game stand out.

Now, did I have fun with it? Yeah i did, but more in the vein of it being a fun co-op shooter with a fairly interesting premise instead of it being a Fear game. I'd expected something else and got a fairly fun co-op shooter that's easy to shoot through.

I recommend this to Die-heard FEAR fans, but even then only if it's on steep discount. Otherwise with the amount of other quality games that come out, buying this game for 20 dollars isn't worth it.
voteText: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the best co-op experiences, endings and credits song ever! Atmospheric horror shooting with two characters from which to choose – each for different playing style. Good graphics and tactical advancement. Also, F.E.A.R.3 has one of the most reasonable achievement system on Steam. The balanced, fast-paced gameplay and intriguing story will keep you going from the beginning until the end for the first walktrough, which takes only about 6-7 hours. But it's not a problem. After the first time, you can take the other character or try multiplayer. Still feels great.

The multiplayer is ok, but nothing exciting.

Despite some managable technical problems, it's one of my favourite games.
Overall rating: 10/10.

NB!There are few technical tweaks you should know, before you play this game.

1. First, rename ClientRegistry.blob file to ClientRegistryOld.blob (Steam folder). This might save you from kicking out, when there are too many players on server (happens around sales time).
2. Manually adjust the FOV, by opening the options.cfg file (game folder) and deleting the # tag and changing value to 85. This will save you from dizziness.

reviewText:
tl;dr Solid FPS with excellent cooperative play.
FEAR 3 is the least scary of the series... I suspect that's mostly down to the coop element. In the quiet spooky bits one tends to be chatting away to your buddy destroying any creepy atmosphere. The story is good but formulaic.
The gun play is solid, with good melee and cover based combat. The guns themselves are a little dull though, and the environments, while varied, get a little dull.
The graphics are mixed with some elements looking very pretty and others looking a bit dated.
Cooperative play is very enjoyable with the different, fairly unique, characteristics of both players both feeling very necessary. You would definitely be losing out by playing this alone.
The other multiplayer mode has up to four players defending against waves of enemies while you build up your defences and armaments between rounds. Seems interesting but haven't yet given it a good play.
All in all good fun and probably just about worth the £30

reviewText:
It's a very good game, firstly played it on the Xbox360, but of course the graphics are much

reviewText:
The first question you have to assume is whether or not F.E.A.R 3 is better or worse than F.E.A.R 2. I really can't answer that because this game is just so... flagrant with it's mediocrity.

F.E.A.R is a tragic series to me simply because of how it strayed so far from it's roots. The original was a great game with non-linear map design, great AI and a very noticeable influence from Hong Kong action movies and horror films. With this game... it just feels like the devs didn't care. Like they went into it knowing it was going to suck so they just went Eh ♥♥♥♥ it" and designed it anyway.

"Eh ♥♥♥♥ it" seems to be a reaccuring philosophy with this game. It continues right from the end of the original game but is so stylistically different it's shocking. The Point Man now looks like a homeless Jesus figure (compared to the faceless balclava wearing professional of the original). At the same time they attempted to do more unique things like playing as your super natural brother Paxton Fettel
date: and the multiplayer has some unique game modes. But if the texture quality and 6 hour campaign don't put you off the mediocrity will. None of the new features feel like they need to be there. Bullet time is completely unnecessary because of the new cover mechanic
recommended: and the new cover mechanic is pointless because we already had bullet time. It's like a ♥♥♥♥ing Catch 22 and all I want is for this series to stop sucking."

reviewText: Paxton Fettel: Be the other guy.\nThis game is not really up to the standard of its predecessors, lacking as it does in spooky time, having weird pre-rendered cutscenes in which they mangle the overarching story, and generally completely losing the strangeness of the paranormal phenomena. Coop mode was fun from both sides, although I think the Fettel experience really carries this game.

reviewText:
This game is actually creepy and actually scary in a startling way, it would be funny to invite your big tough friends over and watch them jump and scream like little girls while you play it. Maybe once I get my new speakers i'll do just that, that will be priceless.

The game itself is pretty straight forward, you go from level to level and kill all the bad guys, each level has different types of bad guys sometimes there are soldiers and sometimes there are psychos with bombs strapped to their bodies and other ones who throw knives at you.

I think for an older game they did really well putting it together, I've never really played a game that was so creepy before, once through the game though I think it will lose its appeal. There is coop and multiplayer which I haven't tried yet, so I can't comment on those things at this time.

reviewText:
Игра вполне хорошая, но это не F.E.A.R. Я ждал больше хорор моментов, неожиданных поворотов и более глубокий сюжет, который смог бы залатать дыры прошлых частей. На деле получилась игра с отличным экшеном(что для меня было на втором плане) но с наитупейшим сюжетом. Да и не то что бы сюжет тупой..просто он топчется на одном месте. Образ поинтмена мне вообще не понравился. Из солдата элитного подразделения феар, он превратился в бомжа. Этот образ ну никак не подходит. И что само бесит - галимый хорор и отсутствие неожиданных сюжетных поворотов. Напугать у разработчиков не получается. Да и эффекты присутсвия Альмы вообще испорчены. Во второй части от каждого появления бегали мурашки по коже.
Разработчики в самом начале поставили не те задачи. Идея превратить FEAR в кооп шутер уже сразу не увенчался успехом.
Вердикт - отличный экшн, слоумоу пыш пыш, но сюжет просто калл. И когда будите принимать решение о покупке игры, подумайте за что вы полюбили прошлые части феар. За сюжет, хорор, или же экшн.
P.S. Я очень хочу увидеть 4ю часть, но что бы в разработчиках значился Monolith. Понятия не имею как можно залатать этот сюжетный бред после 3й части, но в их способностях я уверен.

reviewText: As everyone knows F.E.A.R. is the best game in the series, but the bad rep that F.E.A.R. 3 gets is unfair. As a stand alone game it's very well done, I enjoyed every second of it. It made huge improvements on the damage done to the series by the second game, and the story was captivating. This game may not be right for a long-time F.E.A.R. fan but for anyone who can put their fanboy feelings aside long enough to actually enjoy the game, it's well worth it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Before you buy this game based soley on my recomendation, you should realize that, while it still has its scares, it is not really a horror game anymore. It also has lost much of what made it a great shooter. Why am I recomending it then?

Simple: the co-op is amazing. Most of those 7.5 hours on record? It was with a friend. It was also (unintentionally) hilarious. It's just a by-product of having two college students play through a game that wants you to take it seriously so much. I also have to admit, having Paxton Fettel as a playable character is a nice touch. Combine his ability to posess people with the Pointman's slo-mo powers, and there are some neat teamwork dynamics at play. If you see this game at a price where you can afford to buy it for yourself AND give it to a friend (especially to a funny one,) do so.

However, if you want balls-to-the-wall mind****s, creepy atmosphere, and a gun that can staple people to walls, buy the other two.

Seriously, though, this gun doesn't have The Penetrator? The one weapon that would make Co-op even more hilarious?
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The main reason I'm saying go for this game (preferably on sale) is because it gives closure to the story started back in the first F.E.A.R.  I remember seeing the commercials on TV for this game and apparently had a misconception about how having Fettel as a secondary character would be.  Day 1 did some neat things with the game differently from Monolith, but ultimately I think they fell short of realizing the true potential of the game.

I will say that I did not play the co-op portion at all...mostly because I had no one to play with.  That being said, I did complete the single-player mode, and unlocked Fettel on all missions to replay through again.  I did start this, but quickly lost interest, as the dialogue and almost everything about the game seemed quite repetitive, except you see cut scenes from Fettel's point of view.  I think the game itsefl could have had some awesome variety, as well as some extra gameplay time added for first play-through if the story involved using both characters and switching back and forth depending on the mission or circumstances.

The graphics I thought were much better, the control scheme vastly different, but I got used to it.  I do feel the realism factor increased in fighting by using the reddening screen and then letting the Point Man recover (I'm assuming part of his meta/super-humaness involved an accelerated healing factor).  Sometimes it gets old searching for health packs.

I can't say I was super happy with the ending, but I wasn't disappointed either.  The story seemed to be building up to some amazing climax, but in the end just left me feeling sorry for Alma and wondering if she just wanted someone to be kind to her all along.  The cultish aspect of some of the later levels was a little disturbing, but that seemed to be more of where Fettel's character was going as well.  There's definitely plenty of blood.  Blood on the walls, blood flying from gunshots, knife kills, dripping from bodies and oozing from everyone you meet practically.

I was startled a couple of times....never overly scared...

The variety of antagonists in the game was definitely a little more varied than in F.E.A.R. 2, but I'm guessing because Alma's power was at a max and everyone and everything was being affected more drastically.  Some of the goons you fight were more annoying than anything, and I started to get bored with fighting Replica Commanders very quickly.

If it's on sale, then definitely pick it up, but I wouldn't pay $20 for it.

reviewText:
story and plot:
F.E.A.R. 3 goes on as teh sequel of the F.E.A.R. franchise. The story is very nice but the backround is kinda pourly set.
There are too many details left out making the players make their own assumptions for some things.
In other words there are huge storyholes in the idea. WHich not many players might find good.
On the other hand the plot is quite good. The story gives you the chance to look into more details about some facts.
I won't tell much because that would include spoilers,
however i will say that the plot is actually fully dedicated into finding out more about the main character as one of Alma's successors, taking up the story were you left it on the previous games.

music and sound:
Nothing much to say about music really.
There is a nice addition of music on teh backround, but it's not the kind of music you will be amazed.
The sounds collection though is nice.
Great sounds effects during the FPS gameplay and there is a great set of special scenes that help you enjoy the scary environment of F.E.A.R. 3.
Explosions, gunshots, reloading sound details are all part of a nice gameplay experience.

graphics:
The graphics are fine. Not the greatest thing I've ever seen in my life.
But they left me suttisfied.
The physics and dynamics of the environment are awesome. The developers put the graphics engine is great use.
Walls broken appart, ground torn open, earthquakes and weather effects are some of the things you will find interesting.
The body physics are also very nice, making shooting at your enemies realistic up to a point.

characters:
The game puts you into great details about teh story of the 2 brothers.
The main character has no voiving at all (or at least that's how it still seems like to me after finishing teh game 3 times)
However Paxton Fettel's character voicing is cool by all means.
The face expresions of the characters are not really lifelike, they only take expressions during the video scenes.
The body design is ok, especially Fettel's ghost-flames thing.

gameplay:
The game includes SP and MP gameplay.
Both modes can be experiences through campaign (2 player co-op for MP) AND special survival maps (up to 4 player co-op for MP).
The FPS experience is nice including a taking cover behind items system, slo-mo bullettime mode, a kinda realistic amount of gear to hold, using robots" like mecha armor and a lot more of various stuff.
Also there is a tone of achievements and a ranking system for those who feel more into it.
The campaign during co-op can have 2 kinds of endings depending the way the gamers play teh scenario of teh campaign.

outcome:
This game is nice. In many points of views.
However don't expect to find it scary. The times when we got really scared from such FPS games are possibly over.
It has nice splatter effects and great gun fighting.
The game will make you enjoy it a lot
date: but i have the impression taht it's not teh kind of game you will keep playing with for a very long time.\nThankfully the MP mode adds a lot mroe to teh fun
recommended: and if there is any additional DLC in teh future that would make things more interesting."

reviewText:
FEAR has been apart of my life since it first came out. Hearing the whispers of Alma and having her appear again and again eviscerating and tearing apart anyone in her way. While FEAR 3 is not the favorite among many players...it does keep up with the story along with shocking conclusions and revelations.

The game runs great honestly...while lacking in color.
I run at 4096*2160 resolution and had Reshade and an ENB in my game for the best visuals.
The combat was great, you can take cover, be tactical or use slow mo and take out five men in three seconds.
While there was an obvious lack of jump scares as compared to the first game and its add-ons, the overall atmosphere, gore, ideas and thought in the level detail kind of makes up for it.

I wish Alma could have been more of a main character in this game, even speaking more to the players as a source of background.

Overall it is a great game and a great series. I give it an 8.5/10 since I wish there was more jump scares.

I hope there is a fourth game as well!

reviewText: The final entry in the F.E.A.R. franchise as of this writing, F.E.A.R. 3 provides a much better story than that of F.E.A.R. 2 (which could fit on a post-it and was generally non-existant and boring), better visuals, better performance and much better gameplay. Is it better than F.E.A.R. 1? No, but it's a lot of fun in single player (I don't play co-op) and offers a campaign both as Point Man and Fettel, with the Point Man being the protagnist of the first game and Fettel being a ghost, offering interesting dynamics. The shooting is fast and fluid and the bullet-time mechanics the franchise is known far work beautifully in a series of shootouts involving soldiers and mechs providing a varied challenge. The addition of stick to cover mechanics isn't distracting. Although the shooting takes place mostly in tightly scripted sequences of areas with the occasional signposting problem where you need to look around to figure out where to go next, the steady clip of the action punctuated by good cutscenes maintains a solid pace throughout. A satisfying conclusion to the series that redeems the pathetic F.E.A.R. 2 and although I'd have liked more of the super intelligent AI of F.E.A.R. 1, this'll do.

reviewText: I was thrilled to hear of a third F.E.A.R., and  that it marked the return of the Point Man and Paxton Fettel in earnest. It's an excellent co-op title, offering divergent experiences depending on which character is used. It's generally much more challenging then the earlier titles, affording you meager  regen health and many deaths if you do not take advantage of it's somewhat unusual first-person cover system. Most people dislike this mechanic, I for one enjoyed it in Killzone 2 and in this game. Fettel's powers are a blast to use and there is a satisfying array of weapons. Mechanically, the game is sound. However, it has some story problems. On the whole it is far less creepy the earlier titles, giving Alma a much reduced role and forgoing many scares in favor of more thrilling gun battles. Much like F.E.A.R. 2, it makes little use of prior story elements and opts to take things laterally, offering some interesting backstory but leaving the continuing narrative stagnant.

reviewText: Although the storyline was disappointing (from a long-time F.E.A.R. fan's perspective) and the actual game only took about 6 hours to complete, F.3.A.R. is still a generally enjoyable game. The singleplayer seems to focus more on its action persona than its horror aspect, which was sad to see since the original game had an extremely frightening and terrifying atmosphere. The action is as you'd expect it to be - fast-paced, tight and fun, especially when you activate your slow-mo ability. Plus Co-Op is great with a friend.\n\nThe multiplayer of the game is a pleasant surprise. Modes like Contractions" (where you must survive against an endless wave of enemies) and "F**king Run" (a Left 4 Dead style gamemode where you must travel from one side of the map to the end
date: running from a giant wall of death) are extremely fun and require you to cooperate with your teammates to survive. If you don't
recommended:
you won't last very long.

A solid shooter that just doesn't live up to the original game.

7/10"

reviewText:
FEAR 3 is a good FPS, but the story pales when compared to the first two games in the series. For starters, it's very short. Granted, I played it on easy as I have too many games to play and kind of rushed it, but it was still very short. The story is also extremely simple in plot and I could describe the entire plot of the game in a few sentences.

The plot involves Point Man, the player character from FEAR (the first game). Set nine months after the events of the first two games, Point Man is currently a prisoner in a favela in Brazil and escapes after a psychic connection with his brother, Paxton, the villain from the first game. After escaping the prison, the two of you travel back to Fairport (basically Seattle), to try and reach Alma, the psychic horror inducing woman/girl from the first two games. If you played the first two games, you'd recall that she ♥♥♥♥♥ Beckett, the player character from FEAR 2. Well, you and Paxton crash land in a suburb and have to make your way to the city, teaming up with Jin, the FEAR team member from the first game, and eventually finding Beckett who is being held captive by Armacham, the evil corporation that did the experiments on Alma and you and your brother. I don't wanna spoil the game, but there really isn't that much else to say on the plot. You just fight your way through the city, an airport, the tower, etc, until you reach the endgame.

Being a horror/FPS, I found this to be much less terrifying than the first two games and whenever I saw Alma, I wasn't even phased. It was just kind of like, Oh
recommended: nothing to worry about. Unlike that one time in FEAR where you actually had to shoot her before she reaches you."\n\nThis isn't even a bad game as there actually are elements in this one that aren't in the others. Such as the cover system. At least I'm pretty sure the cover system wasn't in the first two
hoursPlayed: it's been a while since I played them on the 360. But the cover system in this one was probably the best cover system in an FPS I've played
voteText: as you actually stay in first person and can stick to the cover while leaning out.\n\nI guess I can say I was satisfied with this game as it concludes the story of Point Man and Alma

reviewText:
What is F.E.A.R. 3?
--
F.E.A.R. 3 is a twisted sequel to the F.E.A.R. series of psychic-horror first person shooter games. F.E.A.R. 3, however, is more of a co-op arcade cover based FPS with some very light psychic-horror elements.
--
--
Who would most enjoy F.E.A.R. 3?
--
If you're looking for a fast-pased co-op FPS, with a darker twist, F.E.A.R. 3 may be an enjoyable pick-up. The game fails to deliver the ambient terror and jump-scares of the previous title, and has a far weaker delivery of plot than its predecessors. That being said, it can make for an entertaining competative co-op experience, and provides a substantial amount of replay value, if that's what you're looking for.
--
--
Over-all: 62.5%
F.E.A.R. falls short in a lot of areas where the previous titles excelled, providing a weaker experience over-all. The game provides more replayability than any of the previous titles, but with that said, I'm not convinced that this is a good thing, on it's own, as the core gaming experience just isn't enjoyable enough to replay.
--
Mechanics: 3/5
The mechanical flow of F.E.A.R. 3 is inferior to it's predecessor, F.E.A.R. 2. The AI is slightly less interesting, and largely more annoying to play against, the movement and cover system is functional, but not exactly fluid, as are the weapons. On top of this, the bullet-time (core mechanic) feels less fluid and less functional than in previous games.
--
Experience: 2/5
The textures of F.E.A.R. 3 have been updated, but the stylization was a serious turn-off for me. The game felt visually cheap, arcadey, and generally far from immursive. The audio fell short in all regards as well, providing much less emphasis towards the atmosphere than in previous titles, and in places, distracting from the atmosphere (enemy AI call-outs).

Balance: 3/5
Some weapons clearly out-class others, and are just as accessible, and the bullet-time mechanic seems to have been gutted to a degree. This aside, the game is decently balanced, and rarely overly frustrating, but the general balance is anything but remarkable.
--
Longevity: 4.5/5
If you can get past the short-comings of the game, it does provide a lot of content. There's a level-up system, two different viewpoints to play the campaign from, and a fairly decent co-op mechanic. Beyond that, there's a competative element, using an elaborate point system, and for the speed runners out there, a tracker for completion time.

reviewText:
If you're looking at buying this game because you loved the previous games, don't.  It's got very little in common with them except the plot.  It's got none of the atmosphere that the previus games had.  There is no fear.  I am not saying the previous games were all that scary, but they had the genuinely spooky quality to them, F.E.A.R. 3 doesn't.  It really tries to show that it's a F.E.A.R. game, but all the blood and gore in the world won't bring back that feeling you got when you first heard Alma laugh right behind you and when you turn all you see the mere flicker of a shadow run past your periphery.

They took everything that made the first games unique and awesome and made this another COD clone.  They replaced armor and health packs with regenerating health.  They limit your ammo supply, but leave lots of it lying around to pick up.  The SloMo drains too fast and isn't fun to use anymore.  There is no resource management, just run and gun.  The nerf to the SloMo combined with pre-positioned enemies takes all the fun away from anticipating where the enemy is coming from, using SloMo to catch them early and gunning down three to four enemies before they can react properly like the badass you're supposed to be.

I am not saying the games sucks, it's just not I wanted or expected.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The third installment of the F.E.A.R. franchise, F.3.A.R. is an FPS with jump scares and heavy weaponry. It isn't scary in the sense of Amnesia or even Lone Survivor, but more in a scary sense of Doom 3 but kicked up a few notches. I actually did jump a few times in this game, and the huge amounts of gore, spooky lighting, and atmosphere the game throws at you gives you quite an intense experience. The level design is also very good, allowing you to explore extremely spooky areas with blood dripping upwards and dead-eyed teddy bears and dismembered corpses on a regular basis. Speaking of the lighting - it's phenomenal. Some of the best I've ever seen with ambient, red, and even water lighting graphics. It was outstanding. One part that really stands out for me is in an airport terminal. It's raining outside and if you look up you can see the water pooling on the glass ceiling and the lightning flashes and shows rain type effects on the wall and grounds of the terminal. It's a real shame this game tanked and Day1 studios went defunct because this incarnation of the Despair engine is of superb quality.

Another great thing about this game is the co-op. I would *strongly* recommend playing through with a friend as the story and gameplay (each of the two characters is unique and has different abilities/uses in battle) really seems to be geared towards to the co-op mindset and even the ending depends on how the two players play together. Voice chat in the client worked flawlessly and there were no other networking problems that I discovered in a playthrough. There is also a multiplayer mode, but I didn't play that before writing this review and am basing my judgement solely on the single-player experience.

Pros:

Lighting - amazing
Weaponry/Shooting Feels Good" - weapons have "weight" to them
Co-op
Graphics
Ambiance
Reasonably Scary

Cons:

Some Level Design Choices - platforming

The only big con I have with this game is there's a little element of platforming on certain levels where if you fall off something you automatically die and both players have to start back at the checkpoint. This ruins the otherwise excellent co-op gameplay and could be easily rectified with something like the revive mechanic for regular deaths - perhaps hanging onto the ledge and pulling the other player up. Other than that this game was great and I would recommend it for a co-op shooter. B+"
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros: Playing as Fettel can be fun, taking over even strong enemies. Gameplay is challenging. MP modes are varied and interesting.

Cons: The plot barely progresses(as usual), and there's no chilling background info this time. MP is(or was, when I played) bugged beyond playing, and thus dead. The environments are grimy and everything looks the same, in spite of multiple locations. Not much game-play nuance, and few additions to it. The mix of horror and FPS is at its worst here. Even mech-use feels as scripted and linear as it is.

My recommendation: Skip this one. Read the plot online, if you must know it.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is a third part of F.E.A.R. - first person shooter horror series. You have to get scared, you have to shoot, no exact point of the game.

Gameplay / Story
I've played all F.E.A.R.s - 1,2 and finaly 3. Well, I enjoyed first and second part much more than the third. Maybe it is a good story, but the game developers made it look and feel WAY too bad. Seriously, the story is shown very bad - a voice acting is bad, cut-scenes are bad and.. basicly how is story tolerated is bad! Gameplay dissapointed me even more. I cannot say its unplayable, but taking cover, runing, jumping, shooting - it all SUCKS in this game. I mean its so messed up, that it makes camera shake and bug. Speaking of bugs, this game has A LOT of them. I bearly finished the whole game. I thought its the end of the nightmare, but no! There is also a cooperation mode which is EVEN WORSE THAN SINGLEPLAYER. Seriously, its even more unplayable. They shouldn't have even done it. Oh, I almost forgot - I finished whole campaign in 3 hours ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it.

Sounds / Atmosphere / Level design
Whole game sounded like a good game.. but from 5 years earlier. Sounds were more like for a sci-fi game, in a space, on a spaceship - not for a horror game, on Earth, on our freakin planet. Global atmosphere was fatal. Game wasn't scary at all. I finished this during one night and gone to bed with no nightmares. Level design is slighty better, and I can say the best of these three. But the 'open areas' were realy 'closed' sometimes, cause developers were too lazy to make some skyboxes in some locations.

Graphics
Here is what is as bad as gameplay is. I mean, its not THAT bad.. sorry... graphics... BUT YOU LOOK SO MAINSTREAM. Seriously, was that supposed to be a sci-fi game or a horror game? I must say though - models are made very good, and animations are also good (not these for weapons), but everything looks bad because of lame shaders. Damn, developers, that was THAT hard to make a Lens Flare shaders, that you included a fake ones in the sprites? Come on, guys...

So...
as I said - I enjoyed FEAR 1st and 2nd more than 3th part. I do not recommend buying this game if you've got a slow PC. I recommend buying it when its on a bargain, cause 20 ♥♥♥♥in Euros is WAY TOO MUCH for this game.

4.5/10

reviewText:
Background: I'm a very casual shooter fan and pretty undemanding on story while more interested in mechanics and overall experience. Originality certainly helps and appreciate memorable elements of any kind. I rate Crysis 2 as one of the greatest of the genre. I liked FEAR but was indifferent to part 2. Played Fear 3's campaign to the end but little of the multiplayer.

Impressions:
The engine looks ok and the shooting mechanics solid. There's a lot of realism in the world and gun play.. but that world is also drab and the enemies not particularly fun to shoot. The sound is really solid and the grunts chatter is situation appropriate and appears to intelligently adapt to how you engage them. However they also appear to be psychic calling your moves without eyes on you and are impossible to flank as they always seem to have a bead on you which dampens the fun of being a superior soldier, it feels like the game wants you to only ever take on frontal assaults in slow-mo and rely on your healing to save you every time.

Makes 'Dead Space 3' feel like a a masterpiece of horror (another sadly tamed down, but still superior game) as it utterly fails to pull off scares, none are original or unexpected. I noted several early scripted jumps were totally mistimed as I was looking the wrong way or had already moved past the location. Overall there is a lack of polish and placeholder elements are all to obivous, for example flapping fabric elements are replaced with static 1 pixel thick sprites that jut out at as if they are stiff as a board.

The Good:
*Decent graphics and general audio.
*The cover mechanic works well and gives some options.
*Magic healing is handy but almost too handy.
*Gun play is decent but unimaginative.
*Linear route stops you getting lost.
*Grunt conversations are pretty realistic and dynamic.


The Bad:
*Seriously disliked the Main menu interface, found it confusing.
*World is very drab in the early stages and the grunts too hard to see.
*Some textures and locations lack detail that jar in an otherwise more impressive world.
*Gun sights actively make it harder to see the intended target.
*For a cover game you rely on slow-mo far too much.
*Grunts track you too well limiting flanking options.
*Cover mechanic gets tedious and slows down the pace too far.
*Weapons are boring standards and lack oomph or impact.
*Fails at attempts at horror.
*Slow-mo reveals the slack quality as, on a massively overspec'd machine, grunts jink making you deadeye shots miss.
*Stealth seems to only apply when the developer wants you to use it.
*Collectibles, upgrade points break immersion and other console tropes.
*Linear route and narrow locations spoil exploration and experimentation.
*Environment is destructible but rarely has any impact.
*Story is too silly and becomes campy as cut-scenes lack impact and detail.

Recommended for:
3rd person shooter fans not looking for anything special to fill a gap, think more Call of Duty over Bioshock.

Conclusion.
5/10. Seriously disappointing shooter that seems confused by its realistic world and weapons attached to weak fantasy horror setting and characters.

reviewText:
The third installment of the F.E.A.R. franchise, F.3.A.R. is an FPS with jump scares and heavy weaponry. It isn't scary in the sense of Amnesia or even Lone Survivor, but more in a scary sense of Doom 3 but kicked up a few notches. I actually did jump a few times in this game, and the huge amounts of gore, spooky lighting, and atmosphere the game throws at you gives you quite an intense experience. The level design is also very good, allowing you to explore extremely spooky areas with blood dripping upwards and dead-eyed teddy bears and dismembered corpses on a regular basis. Speaking of the lighting - it's phenomenal. Some of the best I've ever seen with ambient, red, and even water lighting graphics. It was outstanding. One part that really stands out for me is in an airport terminal. It's raining outside and if you look up you can see the water pooling on the glass ceiling and the lightning flashes and shows rain type effects on the wall and grounds of the terminal. It's a real shame this game tanked and Day1 studios went defunct because this incarnation of the Despair engine is of superb quality.

Another great thing about this game is the co-op. I would *strongly* recommend playing through with a friend as the story and gameplay (each of the two characters is unique and has different abilities/uses in battle) really seems to be geared towards to the co-op mindset and even the ending depends on how the two players play together. Voice chat in the client worked flawlessly and there were no other networking problems that I discovered in a playthrough. There is also a multiplayer mode, but I didn't play that before writing this review and am basing my judgement solely on the single-player experience.

Pros:

Lighting - amazing
Weaponry/Shooting Feels Good" - weapons have "weight" to them
Co-op
Graphics
Ambiance
Reasonably Scary

Cons:

Some Level Design Choices - platforming

The only big con I have with this game is there's a little element of platforming on certain levels where if you fall off something you automatically die and both players have to start back at the checkpoint. This ruins the otherwise excellent co-op gameplay and could be easily rectified with something like the revive mechanic for regular deaths - perhaps hanging onto the ledge and pulling the other player up. Other than that this game was great and I would recommend it for a co-op shooter. B+"

reviewText:
Pros: Playing as Fettel can be fun, taking over even strong enemies. Gameplay is challenging. MP modes are varied and interesting.

Cons: The plot barely progresses(as usual), and there's no chilling background info this time. MP is(or was, when I played) bugged beyond playing, and thus dead. The environments are grimy and everything looks the same, in spite of multiple locations. Not much game-play nuance, and few additions to it. The mix of horror and FPS is at its worst here. Even mech-use feels as scripted and linear as it is.

My recommendation: Skip this one. Read the plot online, if you must know it.

reviewText: Tight combination of scares and creepiness with basic but solid first person tactical shooter.  A few jump scares and a creepy little girl are the main plot points, and they work although get repetitive by this the third installment (FEAR 2 is my favorite of the series).  Has slow motion time which helps make the game playable for people like myself that don't have great fast twitch reflexes, but if you like a more challenging shooter just don't use the slow mo ability and FEAR 3 will then be plenty challenging.  I’m not a big FPS fan myself, but even so I found the story and scary atmosphere along with the slow mo powers intriguing enough to have played all 3 games in the series, for what its worth.

reviewText: F.E.A.R. is a game series that does a pretty good job at combining the FPS and horror genres by taking aspects from both (Specifically by throwing you into the middle of an intense, non-stop gunfight with jump scares around every corner). F.E.A.R. 3 is a nice addition to the series and a fun game to play my only complaint is that it's just not long enough. There are only a handful of levels that you could knock out on your lunch break which is disappointing seeing as to how intriguing the plot actually is. Still I'd definately reccomend this game to anyone who is a fan of horror games or shooters, crank the difficulty all the way up for maximum intensity.

reviewText:
Summary:

If you are looking for a FPS, buy this.

If you are looking for a F.E.A.R game, don't buy this.


Positive:

-The gameplay mechanics are fluid and crisp.
-Enjoyable combat.
-Graphics are amiable for a modern day game.
-Cheesy lines from enemies. (I like it).
-Will catch you up on the story if you havn't played the first 2 installments (Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate excluded).

Negative:

-The graphics seem a backward step from F.E.A.R 2.
-The story is contradictory and dissapointing.
-It tries to be scary and falls short unlike previous installments.
-Much easier than past 2 installments by taking on a generic health system (I'M LOOKING AT YOU COD), you recover health instead of trying to scavenge it and armour.
-I don't know who thought it would be a good idea to introduce a point based challenge system in order to 'level up'.
-'A lot' of reiteration of previous F.E.A.R story points.
-Do not understand the Replicas' 'deal' this game.
-Alma?

reviewText: F.E.A.R. 3 is amazingly ineffective at getting us to care about the story it's trying to tell, and with no appealing support characters, it pulls you through one bloody explosion after the next. Though what F.E.A.R. 3 lacks in a compelling narrative, it more than makes up for in thrilling first-person shooter combat. With optional challenges as a neat addition to the game, leading to a competitive angle when players compete for points in co-op.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I was a big fan of the first two in the series and was looking forward to an epic apocalyptic conclusion. This game dropped the ball on so many levels. It turned a FPS with an interesting story into just a straight FPS and threw the story away. I did enjoy playing as Fettel, but that was all. Alma was hardly threatening, Sgt Beckett died a pointless death, and the stupid Alma cultists....don't get me started. The graphics were on par with F.E.A.R. 2. I have heard that this game is fun on multiplayer, but I don't buy a game just for a multiplayer option. I buy and play for a story. Fear had it all: action and story!....until now.

reviewText:
After giving it multiple goes after reinstalling it, and finally just sticking with it, I just still can't really recommend it for multiple reasons.

It is obvious that much of this game was made to simply just try to jump onto the success of more modern shooters like Call of Duty, even though the series originated from much of the opposite. Almost every gun except for the shotgun has Aim Down Sights, no more collecting and using med-kits because your health regenerates, only two weapons max, and instead of leaning left and right you press a button to glue yourself to nearby chest-high-walls.

There are so many things wrong with this game not only from the point of an original F.E.A.R. fan, but even when stood on its own.

-Annoying and unrealistic Bloody Screen when wounded, accompanied with fast acting health regeneration.
Completely slows down gameplay, makes certain areas extremely easy due to being near invincible, and makes some areas extremely hard due to not being able to heal instantaneously via med-kit and having to find a spot not being hitscanned into oblivion.

-Kung-fu moves have been chopped out. No punches, just a knife. No bicycle kicks, just one dinky kick. These simple animations made the last games so much more fun, even if the new moves do exactly the same purpose. The aesthetic just isn't the same.

-The first 2 or 3 level designs are ripped straight out of Modern Warfare. Escape the Prison!" "Escape the South American Favela!" Truly takes you out of the F.E.A.R. universe
date: and it's a shame that they thought opening with such unfitting levels would be a good idea when it only helps make an even worse first impression.\n\n-No more finding health and slowmo upgrades throughout the environment. To improve your health and slowmo
recommended: you have to rank up with the new score and challenge system. You can still find hidden dolls and certain bodies that give instant extra "score" (XP really)
hoursPlayed: but it's such a strange decision to add a rank and score system into a game that was basically the opposite of an arcade/points based game...\n\n-The horror aspect of this game was weaker than ever before

reviewText:
Quick Bit- While having the most fully realized combat of the series and an interesting asymmetrical twist with the co-op gameplay, it falls extremely short due to the poor execution of the campaign with both co-op and solo, and the dead-on-arrival multiplayer.

Extra Bit- I love this series, but thankfully the ire it wrought has long since become a dull ache, which allows me to convey a much more mellow expression for F.E.A.R. 3. It can be an enjoyable romp with a friend in co-op, and the odd, but ultimately interesting mechanics that makeup the dynamic brotherly duo of Point Man and Paxton Fettel can be oddly fun, even with the story being insultingly bad, and not enjoyed in an ironic way either.  The game still looks pretty decent, and the combat holds up solid, but of course you will literally need to bring a friend if you want to play co-op. The years have not been kind because like the multiplayer, co-op’s as dead as Alma is. Which is sad, because they did try, but not enough unfortunately to make it shine, and I don’t doubt WB had its gnarled claw in the mix as well. So the legacy ends with a thump, if not for F.E.A.R. Online making a final macabre display of the franchise, at least the name will be remembered for the superb enemy A.I.

I will provide additional details, if requested for, in the comment section of the review.

reviewText:
So after playing the first two games and finding the second one at least decent I was fairly hopeful about the the third one. But no. Fear 3 is comparatively terrible. It feels mostly like any modern military shooter game complete with cover mechanics, auto heal, having only 2 guns at once and a terrible fov. The shooting feels a bit better than in F.E.A.R. 2 and the levels are more diverse (but still hallways) but those are the only advantages compared to the rest of the series.
The whole co-op aspect feels tacked on, Paxton Fettel is annoying and the levels feel too disconnected from each other. That you start every level with basically nothing doesn't help. They don't even really try to bring scares in anymore. It is just running from one part with excessive shooting to another and most non-soldier enemy types aren't even fun to fight. No sir, I didn't like it.

So if you want more F.E.A.R. don't get this. If you want a generic shooter with an a little bit interesting setting. Go for it.

reviewText:
TL;DR - If you like co-op games and have friends to play with, get this game! 9/10 on the co-op scale. If you are a lone wolf type, move along.

This game is great. Not because it is scary, but because the fun that can be had with others. If you were expecting a scary game just try the original F.E.A.R.. It was the only one in the series that was even remotely scary. Otherwise play Amnenisa.

The story is somewhat forgettable but you never feel like you don't know what is going on (I'm looking at you Dead Space 3). The main reason to buy this game is for the co-op. This isn't your standard co-op run and gun either. Each player has their own abilities. While the hardest difficultly isn't extremely hard, you'll have to coordinate who uses what powers to help progress. I really did find this to be one of the best co-op games to date.

F.E.A.R. 3's multiplayer modes also include co-op so there are things to do after beating the main game. Fu**ing Run!" is by far my favorite! This mode has three maps which have you running from a wall could of death. You'll have to maneuver through the map and even enemies as they try to stop you. If one player dies
date: it is game over. So you can't leave anyone behind. Even on easy this is really hard to complete! "Contractions"

reviewText:
Finishing off the FEAR trilogy!

Every time I see FEAR 3 on sale I see people bashing it as the worst in the series, but the meta score is actually not too bad 74/100. Unlike the first 2 FEAR games, FEAR 3 has one of those regenerating health systems where you just hide under cover for a few seconds and you recover back to full health. No need to scrounge for med kits or armor. Also, the game seems built around 2 player co-op, which I like in first person shooter games (when I have someone to play with).

*Spoilers ahead*
FEAR 3 takes place an unspecified amount of time after the events of FEAR 2. Alma is pregnant and getting ready to give birth, as a result her psychic power is tearing up the city (possibly the world). Again the main opposition is the private military contractor Armacham, who seems to have become 100x more powerful than they were in the first games. Even without their clone super soldiers from the first games, Armacham seems capable of overrunning and occupying entire cities with soldiers, aircraft, and power armor. You play the Point Man protagonist from the first FEAR game (the guy you play in FEAR 2 also shows up briefly) but this time you have an “imaginary” friend Paxton Fettel (Bad guy from the first game). Your primary goal this time around is to reach Alma before she gives birth and deal with her once and for all. Unfortunately for you, Alma’s psychic pain has summoned nightmare creatures and twisted the surviving civilian population into crazed psychos.

Unlike the previous FEAR games, FEAR 3 is broken down into missions or “levels” with each mission giving you a point score at the end. You gain points by finding collectables, killing enemies, and completing “challenges.” The challenges are similar to the “Skill shots” in Bulletstorm, where it’s basically just using various methods of killing. For example, 2000 points for killing enemies with a specific weapon, or 1000 points for getting 25 headshots, or 2000 points for getting 3 backstabs. The points aren’t just for show, by the way. You “level up” when you gain enough points and each level gives you some kind of perk, such as +10% health or +bullet capacity. You can replay levels as many times as you want to “grind” for points. This means that the game will get easier over time as you replay it. You might notice that when you first start the game, it seems far more difficult than the previous ones, well this changes as you level up and get stronger. The regenerating health means you can charge groups of enemies and just duck for cover when your screen is almost completely red (near death). Healing is free unlike FEAR 1 and 2 which had limited med kits.

As I mentioned earlier, the game is built with 2 player co-op in mind. At the end of each mission there is a ranking between the 2 players to see who scored highest in several categories. The game’s ending depends on which of the two characters “won” the most missions. Of course if you’re playing single player the character you’re playing (Fettel or Point Man) will “win” every level you complete. Point Man’s gameplay is the same as the previous games (standard shooter with Slow-Mo power), But Fettel is a psychic commander. This means he can possess enemies and use them to fight (he doesn’t have slow-mo). Every time he takes over a new body he gets the weapons of the possessed enemy, so you can’t hoard powerful weapons or grenades the way Point Man does. You can only hold 2 weapons now, unlike 3 weapons in FEAR 1 and 4 weapons in FEAR 2. Possession also means you won’t be able to use the awesome power armors because the possessed body won’t last long enough.

Pros:
+Excellent graphics and visuals. Large variety of weapons available.
+Some cool new enemies, particular the Phase Commander and Phase Caster.
+A lot of replay value. I just finished the game and immediately restarted as Fettel.
+2 player co-op available. Also a bunch of various multiplayer game modes I haven’t tried.

Cons:
-The game is very short, about 6 hours to beat the first time. Replay is strongly encouraged though.
-The story is weaker than the first FEAR games. There’re a lot of unnecessary “dream sequences” that don’t seem to add much. You just walk forward about 15 seconds with someone talking in voice over and it ends.
-I get the feeling that the enemies are much “dumber” than FEAR 1 enemies. They tend to stick behind the same piece of cover and just pop their heads out to shoot from there.

Overall I think the game is well worth playing for fans of First Person Shooters and people who want to see how the FEAR story ends. Once you finish a mission in single player, the Fettel character is unlocked so you can try playing him for that particular level. The way to see the Fettel game ending is by playing through the game a second time (or play the game in co-op and Fettel has the highest score every mission). One thing I noticed is that the game’s Steam achievements seem to be half for multiplayer, and not many people are playing the multiplayer. This isn’t surprising since the game has been out for a few years. I’ll probably only be able to get about 45% completion for the game achievements by myself.

reviewText: I think Monolith are trying to run their business to the ground. I was certain that they had done the worst game that they possible could with F.E.A.R. 2, but lo and behold, they have proven me wrong. Amazingly, F.3.A.R. does the impossible and manages to be even worse than its predecessor. The horror elements were pretty much reduced to quick-time events in F.E.A.R. 2 and have been binned altogether by the third game; the gameplay is as uninspiring as ever with most enemies taking all of one headshot to kill; the story is completely nonsensical even if you ignore the first game and worse still if you do take it into account; and instead of the perplexing abortion of an ending that we got in F.E.A.R. 2, we now have TWO of the bloody things. Happily, the third game is even shorter than the second, taking only about three and a half agonizing hours to trawl through.\n\nAvoid like a crotch rot.

reviewText:
Ok. Let me start by saying I'm a HUGE fan of the first two games. They both bring something different to the table and they had all the atmosphere, scares, and visceral combat the franchise is known for.

F3AR Is severly lacking the simplest way this is not a FEAR game. There is a new studio, a new engine - and entirely new writers. Let me start with some gameplay changes:

The persistent weapon carry system is gone - there is now a 2 weapon limit that resets upon the start of each new chapter. Don't bother saving up and trading off a weapon for a fully filled rocket launcher unless you plan to use it, because It'll be gone at the end by the time the cutscenes come up. The health/armor system is gone and in place is a regenerating health system. This hurts the gameplay due to the fact that you can simply melee the majority of the jump mosters and sit healing before moving to the next trigger- it kills the adrenaline entirely. The classic replicant variants are gone in favor or new, completely arbitrary lore-breaking entities with poor voice acting and predictable movement. The classic FEAR A.I. is gone, and what they've implemented here is atrocious. Many times elite" AI will sit in a single place ducking behind cover while I set up for the next headshot. The booster/reflex injector mechanic is gone in favor or hoping players will alter their play to "score up" and unlock the next level
date: which merely increases your grenade and slo-mo meter. The slo-mo is the weakest yet
recommended: and drains much too fast and takes obnoxiously long to refill... The problem with this is that the award/score system is fundamentally flawed with things like giving you points for fully draining your meter 3 times in a chapter. The game rewards you for time in cover

This would be all fine and dandy but the co-op quickly turns into PVP with the ending of the entire game dependant on who gets the highest score overall. The clever level design and setpieces of the first are instead shifted here with lackluster textured environments that are riddled with tacky cover points much similar to gears of war and other 3rd person titles. The cover system hardly needs to be utilized
votesFunny: as a crouch toggle behind cover works faster - BUT - it doesn't give you the score points for staying in cover X amount of seconds (what?). The linearity and uninspired level design pushes further by unrealistic structures with only a handful of recycled items scattered throughout - this kills the immersion entirely. The intel items from FEAR 1 and FEAR 2 are gone

reviewText:
I'll say right off the bat that I am indeed a fan of the original F.E.A.R. game, I do not like the second one very much, and I think this third game is a complete atrocity. I promise I tried to make this review short, but there's just so much to say... Sorry. Let us begin.

I shall also mention that, at the time of writing this review, I have completed the game twice - once as Fettel, once as the Pointman. I have not yet played the coop, although I'm sure it'll be a grand old time.

Right off the bat, it is glaringly obvious that this game is intended to be cooperative. Is that a bad thing? Well, not inherently, coop shooters have been around for a very long time and there are a couple examples of cooperative horror done right. That is to say, it is still very scary indeed in spite the fact that you are not alone. However, given the fact that F.E.A.R. 3 doesn't deserve to be called a horror game - I'll get to that later - that's a rather moot point. So, you play as either the Point Man from the first game, or his brother Fettel. The Pointman obviously has bullet time, and Fettel the ability to possess enemies for a given time. I will say that the Pointman plays how you expect him to, no problems there, and Fettel is quite fun to play as well with what seems - to me, anyway - to be a rather well fleshed-out special ability. However, at the same time, it seems well balanced to the Pointman's and the enemies around. Although it would not surprise me if it is commonplace to fight to get Fettel over the Pointman.
Getting back on topic, coop in itself is not an issue really, but I do believe that it was one of the big downfalls of this game. I shall elaborate at the end of this review.

The second glaringly obvious addition which made me very upset when I first saw it was the inclusion of a per-level point system, complete with goals to earn you additional points which are snarkily or punnily named. Well, that's not very F.E.A.R.-like at all, now is it? Or horror-game like in general, really. Why, you ask? Well, in terms of U.I. and game mechanics, having a score system - let alone one with a little status menu you can look at in-game (by pressing F1) - kinda breaks the player's immersion. Maybe a post-mission stats screen would be okay, but having nothing at all - like in the last two F.E.A.R. games - would be a lot better. Hell, in the first game, immersion was one of the biggest things they were striving for! Hence the inclusion of such details like a full shadow for the player, good arm models, and the ability to look down and actually see your legs and feet. Same with the stigma the first game had about never taking control away from the player when possible. There were probably two cutscenes in the first game, and most of the times control is taken away from you is a few seconds after something whacked you on your butt and your person gets up, and even then it's almost nice as a breather between the action. This game, on the other hand, of course has that point-system, and cutscenes galore; the things bookending every single level.
Although to be honest, immersion is a bit of a moot point with the lack of actual scares in the game...

Let's get onto the horror elements, now. Or rather the lack-there-of. This game is not a horror game at all, it is a first-person shooter through and through. What makes me say that? Well, there are only four or five times in the entire game where it even tries to scare you or creep you out - and those times a very shortlived and ineffective. Going in fully blind, I didn't even get that sense of dread and not wanting to keep moving forward like I did in the first game. It did make me jump once in fear, although that was when I was walking through a seemingly empty house and an enemy - unintentionally - snuck up behind me and started yelling while clawing at me. T'was unexpected, but I don't think most people would even get scared by that - assuming they were playing it like one should an FPS; keeping their head on a swivel. There really just seemed like a lack of effort with the scares, to be honest. While I am sure they did try their best with the scary moments that are present, keep in mind there's literally four or five of them.

Alright, so because this game is an FPS now, let's cover that next.
The short version? It's your standard console shooter. What do I mean by that? Well, we now have regenerating health, a full cover system, a two-weapon carry limit, a very standard assortment of weapons outside of two which are even then not too interesting. You read that right, regenerating health in a F.E.A.R. game. A cover system, too, which I thought at first was kinda nice and was a change I'd be indifferent too. However, about midway through the game on my first run, I had a realization; the cover system was killing the pace of the combat. Hell, there's practically no need for the Pointman's bullet time given this. Just play it like you would Gears of War or similar and you're good to go. There's no panic or amazing action like in the first game, where there was no cover, and you had to be quick and clever to take out a whole squad. Though this was helped by a normal - or nowadays 'old school' - health system which, of course, gave you one-hundred points of health, and up to ten medkits which healed you a certain amount at the press of a button. Here, even if you try and replicate the amazing shootouts you remember from the original F.E.A.R. - and even the second game to a lesser extent - you're going to die, because the very nature of the regenerating health system doesn't allow such things. Even if you pull it off, you're just handicapping yourself really.

However, then I had a thought. I stopped thinking about it as a F.E.A.R. game. Suddenly things got a lot better. This isn't a lazy, poorly made cash-in in my eyes, it was just made with the wrong license. If this game didn't have the F.E.A.R. title attatched to it, I would like it a hellofalot more. There was effort put in, and it is certainly fun to play at points, and at it's worst it's just like any other standard MMS (Modern Military Shooter), and I'm sure it'll be a blast when I get around to coop. It just shouldn't have been a F.E.A.R. game.

While this is byfar the worst game in the F.E.A.R. franchise, but it's not a bad game on its own. Unless you count modern shooters bad, and I don't disagree with you if you do.

reviewText:
A bit about the game and developers.
F.E.A.R. 3 has been developed by Day 1 Studios, and published by Warner Bros. They have been publishing many different games so I won't mention any of them at the moment. F.E.A.R. 3, or Fear3 for short is a horror game which continues the story of the first two parts.

About Gameplay.
Fear 3 offers three different types of gameplay, singleplayer, co-op and multiplayer. Single player and co-op both have the same story to go through. Single player is much more challenging thought. The game is a continuation of the first two FEAR games, therefore in Fear 3 you play as Point Man, a guy who you have been playing as since the first FEAR game, while your friend gets to play Fettel, your badass ghost brother who you killed in the first game. Point Man's only power is to slow down time and react quicker, while Fettel can choke people, consume their body and so on and on.

The multiplayer is something different from the other games. In Fear 3, multiplayer is a survival game. A survival in which you need to gather crates and put them in a specific area to unlock more weapons, which will then help you survive more and more rounds. The only sad thing about it is that the multiplayer has died out completely, and I wasn't able to find even a single server. But then again, playing with people you know is always more fun than with strangers!

The game also has a handful selection of guns. There's not many of them and they are not too special, but it's always fun to try out new stuff. Thought, you will always find yourself mainly using the start gun that you obtain in the very early part of the game. On come co-op missions you even get to use a mech, which is very, very fun to play with!

Graphic and Audio
Graphic of this game is pretty good, but nothing out of the ordinary. Audio is okay but it does get rather empty most of the time.


Pros, cons and final grade.
Pros:
- Nice Co-Op experience.

Cons:
- Multiplayer is dead
- The game does not bring anything new.

Final Grade: 4/10

Extra Info: It actually took me a long, long time to write this review. I just didn't know what to write about the game. It's a very fun co-op game, but.. Nothing special. If you can get it cheaply, go for it.


Thank you for reading my review! Don't forget that I'm doing weekly reviews on my blog! The page of my blog is:
http://midnightwolfie.blogspot.com

reviewText: Not your daddy's FEAR. It's a step down from FEAR1 and definitely a huge change of pace. But it's got satisfying shooting, interesting set pieces (I mean that, I can REMEMBER every specific battle in this game. How many shooters have that many memorable fights? This game does a lot to shape each encounter so it feels unique.), a cute scoring system, and some colorful environments.\n\nIt's not great but it's a game that really had some love put into it. The regen health is a pain and the cover system works on consoles but is awful on PC but it does not hinder the game. A solid effort and a fun time-waster. Better if you can do it in co-op.

This game waters down F.E.A.R. 2 even further with regenerating health, a higher reliance on action sequences and shootouts, forgettable music, awful pre-rendered cutscenes, a decreased quality in visuals, and scares that fail to impress. The story itself returns to the series' main protagonist, but the game fumbles with its momentum, switching between action and horror sequences too quickly. The game can hardly don the style psychological horror" as most of the scary elements are tangible
date: such as crazed humans or otherworldly monsters.\n\nThere are no terrorizing setpieces like in the previous two games. Even F.E.A.R. 3's scariest moments are nothing compared to sequences like the school basement or the failed commander experiments from the previous game. reviewText:
Do you like horror games? No? Do you like gunwank? Yes? Do you take yourself too seriously? Yes? Then this game is for you.
If you enjoyed the horror of being alone in a place you don't fully understand, with the only things explaining what happened being bloodstains and unread voice-mails in FEAR 1, then stay. The ♥♥♥♥. Away.
I unlocked an achievement literally 5 minutes in to the game by killing 3 enemies while being in bullet time, with a small colourful box popping up in the corner notifying me of my glorious, unique talent.

If you got someone stoned out of their mind, sat him in front of a pc and every 15 minutes changing between FEAR 1, Saints Row III, and CoD Ghosts and then asked him to sum up the experience, this is most likely what you'd get.

Don't buy if you respect the franchises' integrity at all.


Edit: I played the game for 20 minutes, then I had to ragequit, as I was informed of almost unlocking another stupid achievement, and remembered that I, in fact, don't find arbitrary, useless rewards" satisfying in a bloody horror game. That is why it says that I have 0h playtime."

reviewText:
Day 1 Studios gave the new F.E.A.R. game the refreshing stimulus the franchise has deserved after the second entry. While F.E.A.R. 2 was a solid FPS it was also old with ageing mechanics that couldn't held up against the best in the genre. The latest game became modernish with updated gameplay mechanics. On one hand it was a good decision (it had to be done), on other side it isn't unique enough to separate itself from the competition.

F.3.A.R starts off 8 months after the second game. Point Man is our protagonist once again and he has to team up with his long gone brother, Fettel to get out of a prison and find his squad mate, Jin, who is in danger. Paranormal activities are a big part of this game too. Only this time around Alma isn't the antagonist, but something called the Creep. The story of the game won't leave any deep marks in you. It's flat and uninteresting. It's hard to take the story seriously when it doesn't prove its worthiness. Your personal goal will be reaching checkpoints after checkpoints to beat campaign. And it will be done after just around 6 hours. It's a shame really because with a more intriguing story this game could have made a mark.

Luckily F.E.A.R. 3 isn't short on content. Not at all. After completing the campaign you can kill your time with various game modes. Many of them are essentially a modified version of the original campaign, but the changes made in those modes are not only worth a try but also great fun. The campaign is made of 8 intervals, each of them takes around 30-45 minutes to complete. After completing an interval you can replay it as Point Man or Fetter with all its unique psychic abilities. He has the ability to posses common enemies. You'll appreciate the change of pace.

Also, you can hop in a co-op campaign with your friend. One controls Fettel the other Point Man. It isn't a novelty at all, but great to see the developer putting in the game options like this. When you exploit everything the single player modes can offer there is a multiplayer option in the game. Sadly the multiplayer of the third game was never as popular as the first game's MP. If you want to try this option most likely you have to play with your own friends as very few gamers are left playing F.3.A.R. over the internet.

Moving to different territories, the looks of the game are passable. It's isn't a beautiful, nor a bad looking game. To its defense they put more emphasis on minor details, so this time a book on a table will actually look like one instead of a bunch of blurred pixels. The gameplay has been completely refreshed. The previous game in the franchise was getting old and set back by wrong decisions during the development. Not this game though. It feels like a modern shooter where you bullets do matter. When you shoot a soldier in this feet he grabs it or tumbles and the gunfight is much more vivid and powerful. Day 1 made the right decisions to cut the useless features and refresh the remaining ones. It's a great shooter, but beyond that it offers nothing more. Nothing that could differentiate this game from the others.

Fear in F.E.A.R. 3 is almost non existent. There are moments here and there when you'll look around suspiciously, but that's about it. The franchise has switched genres over the years. From psychological horror it became a solid action oriented shooter. We can't say it was a bad decision, but we can say that there isn't many horror games in the market while there's a legion of action shooters to choose from; good, bad or worse. It's a pity that in this era a franchise has to get more action oriented to survive, and sometimes even that might not be enough. Again, F.E.A.R. 3 is a great shooter and it definitely benefited from the changes made around it, but the industry and the gamers might not.

Rating: 80/100; Replay Value: 3/5; To Beat: 6 hours; Played on: normal.

reviewText:
I really couldn't bring myself to finish F.E.A.R. 3. It was so lacklustre in comparison to its far superior predecessors, to the point where it was simply the stuff from my nightmares.

Gunplay in F.E.A.R. 3 is sluggish and boring. While the guns sound impressive, I find the aiming and movement mechanics to be too wavy for my tastes. Getting a bead on enemies is awkward, saved only by the Slo-Mo mechanic that was also present in the previous two games. Even adjusting the sensitivity failed to improve anything. When playing arcadey-style shooters, I expect fast, fluid and responsive combat. F.E.A.R. 3 has none of that.

Graphically, the game is laughable, looking like an Xbox 360/PS3 launch title at best. The atmosphere is foggy and ugly, and is nowhere near as immersive as the dark, claustrophobia-inducing corridors and areas that the original F.E.A.R. harboured. The game is completely lacking in the horror department, resorting only to cheap jump scares instead of the subtle, eerie hallucinations and sound effects that the made the first game so terrifying. Even the presence of a bloodied, heavily pregnant Alma failed to make me jump and cower behind my chair in terror.

Multiplayer is quite fun. F**king Run is intense and challenging enough on its own, but the sluggish gunplay made experiencing it nothing short of a nightmare; no pun intended. On the plus side, most servers were lag-free and performed reasonably well.

Apologies for the short review, but I really can’t say much more about F.E.A.R. 3. The game was so boring and awkward to play that I simply couldn’t bring myself to play more than a few hours of it. Half-decent multiplayer and a woeful singleplayer campaign does not justify a playthrough, even at the €5 price tag that I bought this game at. A waste of money and time. It truly is the black sheep of the F.E.A.R. series, and anyone who enjoyed the previous two iterations would do well to stay away from this tosh.

Being one of the worst FPS games I have played in recent memory, F.E.A.R. 3 gets a 3/10.
