reviewText:
F.E.A.R 3 is a strange game, it needs a series of requirements to be met for it to be a very, very good experience, otherwise, there are just better games to spend your money on, let me give you a quick list of what you need:

- A partner, Fear 3 is much, MUCH better with a partner. The enemy AI really shines when you see it actively trying to flank your friend or yourself, asymetric coop is tons of fun and its just a much better, overall experience.

- A controller, I know many will think playing an fps with a controller when you have a perfectly good M/KB setup is some sort of sacrilege, but sadly the game has mouse acceleration and little bit of autoaiming enabled (with no ways to remove them), also the FoV is locked to 65 (can be changed by editing a config file), so a controller will just give you the better experience (sadly on screen inputs are locked to the keyboard, oh well).

- A complete disregard for the prequels, Fear 3 is not scary (at all) but it has a good atmosphere, the story is mediocre at best, try to think of it not as a Fear game but as a good coop game.

Okay let me wrap this up quick, still a good game, some of the multiplayer game modes can be fun if you can get some people in them (online is dead), graphics are nice, so is sound, game has decent graphic options, input options are lacking, no button mapping for the controller (default is pretty good tho). It's fun, you like fun.

reviewText: I've played FEAR 1 & 2, lots of other horror games and here's what I have to say about FEAR 3....a letdown!  In a nutshell FEAR 3 feels like Call of Duty with a ghost that appears every so often.  FEAR 1 & 2 had major moments of scares and making you feel like you were always haunted.  FEAR 3 is just bad guys, bad guys and more bad guys...then Alma shows up and is gone.  I acknowledge that FEAR 3 is a shooter game but I think it concentrates too much on shooting and not the horror.  Furthermore, I'm upset that you can shoot an enemy in the face a couple of times then he gets back up and shoots and granades you a dozen times.  The AI is a bit too smart as well.  Before you round the corner they're already shooting at you!  Forget ducking for cover because they seem to have an unlimited supply of granades.  By the time I reached a ghost moment" I was so frustrated that I was basically like
date: whatever Alma just get outta my way go haunt someone who cares!  The creepy moments are very brief and and they're ok but far from great.  If you like horror games stay away from this
recommended:
it'll be a letdown.

Pros:
+Controls (after changing them from default)
+Ablility to use cover during a firefight
+Weapons

Cons:
-Graphics (worse than FEAR 2 for some reason)
-Enemies keep spawning in some places
-Enemies hard to kill even at point blank
-No real scary moments
hoursPlayed: not a true horror game\n-For a shooter/horror game it's boring."

reviewText:
I've been meaning to complete the FEAR anthology for some time now having played the original FEAR some years ago, so when they came on sale for the anthology I couldn't resist. I'll admit I've played (approximately) half of the original FEAR, and completed FEAR 3, so I will only reveal story information without ending spoilers pertaining to FEAR 3.

You start out nine months after the ending of the first two games, captured protagonist known as the point man held in south america works to escape with the assistance of Paxton Fettel after interrogation. Brothers in arms Point Man who is the Wolverine-like protagonist and Paxton a spectre. During their escape, they discover that they are being hunted along with their mother, Alma. The creature seeking to kill the family was created based on the evil memories of the mother, and this evil has formed a strange paranoia over Fairport. In order to restore the balance, the brothers set out to destroy any memories associated to the past to weaken the monster hunting them.

The game sets a good base story and introduces a very cool horror element. There was some supernatural element introduced that didn't really fit but the actual horror side of the supernatural was a perfect buttery fit and it got a couple of good jumps from me. The story is particularly hard to follow until you get three quarters in but once you get there the story and gameplay make much more sense and the game goes from being somewhat random to making sense.

After completing all but the last few chapters, the game really picks up and becomes a lot more fun. The horror elements in the last chapter were the highlight as the story became very clear in this chapter and it really felt like an action horror where as the rest of the game was scattered between action and horror but never the two. The game is short, sweet, but it's also lacking in story and fun comparring to its original - of which I recall having a lot of fun in my youth. I have heard from a lot of people complaining that this game fell short of its original, I can agree and understand, but there's no denying you'll have fun in this game because you will.

I feel it more of a casual game due to the points system, it feels like it was created for its points system and not its story. Yje lack of story in the beginning, the point system and its linearity all contribute to the downgrade of this games reception to me. It does become repetitive when all you need to do is shoot until everybody is dead, move into next section and repeat the entire game. I have an issue with that, but there's no real interaction or immersive features.

It's a solid game and it runs well on old technology. Getting a jump or two makes you smile, and the whole composure results in a great story and a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Ugh.  See my FEAR and FEAR2 reviews for necessary context, but the pros are few and far between here:

1) Even better graphics, but lackluster, repetitive and at times confusing level design.

2) Genuinely bad AI.  It also seemed like there was some fairly cheesy enemy spawning going on, and while it was sometimes hard to tell, there is no doubt that the scary-good AI of the original game is gone for good.

3) Gunplay is definitely a serious regression from FEAR and FEAR2.  Everything has a very arcadey feel to it now, which is only compounded by the braindead AI and level layouts.  Plus, you can only carry two weapons and a small number of grenades, and your health now regenerates.  I play games like this INSTEAD of Call of Duty and the like, since they reduce the difficulty and tension pretty drastically for me.  Walked into an ambush and are on the verge of death?  No problem!  Just crouch behind a box for a few seconds, emerge from cover in slow-mo, and faceroll the AI.

4) Achievements. Why are there achievements unlocking in-game, in real time, as I play a story-driven horror FPS?  Immersion is critical in games like this, and fewer things take me out of that more than random unlocks for X slow-mo kills" or the like popping up on my screen during firefights or scare moments.  Too much of this felt like priming players to jump into MP
date: rather than to enjoy the SP mode.\n\n5) Not at all scary.  There are definitely some disturbing and interesting revelations
recommended: but many of the plot developments are spoon-fed to the player
hoursPlayed: rather than being discovered and experienced organically.  Even the things that do come about more naturally still felt forced on some level and certainly weren't frightening.\n\n6) The game's final act is a huge disappointment story-wise.  Again
voteText: I don't want to spoil it verbatim here
helpfulPercent: but I did not feel that the Point Man's "good ending"--which I view as the game's intended ending--really made that much sense.  We never really understand the mind-state of Alma
votesHelpful: and nor is her resolution or the implications of the child ever really made clear.  Fettel's "bad" ending certainly followed more logically
votesTotal: so perhaps its more apocalyptic and nihilistic tenor is truer to the nature of the series overall.\n\nSadly
votesFunny: this game largely self-destructed where it counts
commentsCount: leading to a rather unenjoyable and ignoble end to what could and should have been a great series.  Take a pass and go play the original FEAR again instead."

reviewText:
A great climactic way to round out the series.

It doesn't really try to frighten you so much as the first one did, but then again at this point in the series you should be used to what is going on.

As the first one touched on the supernatural and the second installment delved further...this third one goes balls deep.

Non-stop adrenaline all the way through - two storylines to play through - one for each brother.
That's right, play as not only Point Man, but his brother Fettel for the first time ever.
Decimate waves of enemies with your psionic abilities and view the alternate ending!

Recruit, Commando, Fearless & Insane difficulties to playthrough.

9/10 - Thoroughly enjoyed it, I recommend it.

reviewText: As a shooter FEAR 3 holds its own just fine, using the previous games as its foundation. As a single-player experience it does almost nothing to improve on the series’ formula, keeping mostly the same enemies, similar mech suits, almost all the same weapons, and the same scare tactics. As a co-op campaign, the game becomes significantly more interesting, but we’ll talk about that in a bit. Despite the lack of changes to the formula, the shooting is still solid, the slo-mo is still satisfying, the gore is nice and crunchy, and the weapons have hefty power. The level design still hasn’t strayed all that much from the much-criticized “gray corridors” of the first FEAR – sure, you explore suburban houses, a Costco-like store, a huge bridge, and even a forest, but much of the time you’re still in monochrome corridors.

reviewText: F.E.A.R. 3 is a fun and well polished shooter, IF you're looking for a fun casual experience a la Call of Duty, but do NOT mistake it for a sequel to the excellent F.E.A.R.. The gameplay has now become a mix of Parkour and fast paced gunfights, the goal being to make the highest score by replaying the same levels, over and over.\n\nInterestingly, the campaign can be played in co-op, but this makes the game a little too easy, so I would recommend to finish the game in solo first. The game also features some very original multiplayer game modes. In F*king Run, up to six players are tasked to escape from an ever advancing fog of death, while the players are being pursued by an increasing number and tougher enemies. This game mode is exceptionally fun and challenging. Contractions is a survival mode tasking the players to barricade themselves from waves of possessed enemies. Unfortunately, nowadays it's impossible to find anybody playing multiplayer games or the cooperative campaign.

reviewText:
Rating 7/10
Overview: FPS with the ability to go into slow-mo

The Good

+ The game features 2 main characters you can play as. You first have to complete the game as 'point man'. This character allows you to slow down time while you blast away your enemies. The other character is Paxton Fettel who has the ability to possess almost any enemy in the game.

+ A cover based system in a first person shooter never seems to work out, yet this game handles the feature nicely. With a single press of a button  you can hide behind cover and easily pop out and shoot your enemies.

+ By completing challenges you acquire experience which is then used to level up your character. Challenges include killing a certain amount of enemies with a weapon, getting headshots, staying in slow-mo for a certain amount of time etc. It's a nice addition and it helps you change up your play style so you're not constantly relying on the same tricks over and over again.

+ I feel the AI has improved (yet still lacking to the first FEAR), enemies flank, hide, take cover and feel like a genuine threat when facing them.

+Variety of different weapons and grenades

+The shooting mechanics feel good, going into slow-mo and shooting enemies is always fun. The game also introduces sections where you ride a mech to change up the gameplay.

The Average:

On a technical level the graphics are decent. Textures are solid, lighting and shadows look decent however artistically the game feels bland and uninspired. Poor color usage and levels that feel and look the same despite being in different environments doesn't help either.

The story is decent but it really is starting to feel convoluted at this point.

Game will provide around 5-7 hours for one playthrough. Multiplayer and playing through the campaign as the second character can extend playtime for a bit.

The game features some multiplayer modes that can be played in single player and extend your game time. The problem is that multiplayer is dead which is sad given that some of these modes looks really fun to play.

The Bad

- multiplayer is dead which also means getting certain achievements is now impossible

- no local co-op


Conclusion

The more FEAR games we get the farther we move away from what made the original so great. This game lacks even less horror elements and tactical shooting from the previous entries and is essentially a straight up first person shooter with the slow-mo ability. I don't consider this a bad game but compared to the last 2 entries it feels like it took 2 steps back and 1 step forward.

reviewText:
This game is an insult to the original FEAR. The AI has been dumbed down, the guns feel weightless and sound dull, the atmosphere has been gutted to be another action FPS, the HUD is a cluttered mess, a completely pointless XP system has been added, the lighting and effects are not as impressive as they used to be, the list goes on and on. I've seen people say the co-op makes this game bearable, but I found this to be completely untrue.

My first playthrough was co-op with my best friend and as my Steam hour count shows, we couldn't make it past the first few hours. What we played was just another mass-manufactured action shooter with none of the attention to detail of the original.

The original FEAR was not perfect. However, what in lacked in level design and enemy variety it made up for with superior gunplay, spectacular effects and lighting, and a haunting atmosphere. FEAR 3 has none of that. It's a homogeneous clone of every other popular FPS on the market to appeal to widest common denominator. Such a damn shame.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If this game was released as its own title, it honestly might have done a lot better. As a fear game it is quite unfaithful.

The game itself is actually pretty fun to play, and the multiplayer contractions mode was really cool. Basically you fight waves of illusionary soldiers/creatures, and between waves you can repair barricades and collect weapon caches.

The single player is trash, almost entirely due to the fact that it's so unfaithful to the original. From the mood to the guns and atmosphere, it's weird. Like uncannily weird. You spend a lot of time fighting in spaces like suburbs, supermarkets and airports. Where as in FEAR 1 and 2 the game was  more localized around industrial areas and downtown cityscapes, it feels very weird to spend your time fighting in these much less industrial areas.

This game is also not scary at all. I really don't remember anything in the game that was legitimately scary in the same vein of the first two games. But to be fair I also feel like the game ended up way past its prime, I think the original theme was already played out to death, the way the story pans out in this last game makes light of the entire supernatural threat from the first two games.

So basically, it's call of duty with spooky stuff, except the spooky stuff is on your side. Or something.

reviewText:
What can I say about F.E.A.R 3? Quite obviously, It's the 3rd game in the F.E.A.R franchise, which, one would expect, would say everything. But in all honesty, it doesn't - in fact, the third installment of the F.E.A.R franchise is much more akin to the generic first person shooter than the trouser-browning horror shooter that the F.E.A.R name is otherwise known for.

The gameplay is, to put it in one word, generic. You have guns, they go bang, there are a LOT of enemies to shoot with them, same old. However, the genericness is tempered slightly with a very nice cover system, the slow-mo mechanic which is a mainstay of the F.E.A.R franchise, and the occasional creepy moment, though undoubtedly nothing as trouser-wetting as the previous games in the series, which I have admittedly not actually played a lot of. There is also some geo-mod, but this is needless and hinders more than it helps. However, the game is still relatively fun despite the genericness and shortcomings.

The story is confusing. Whilst playing through the game I had little idea of what was actually going on, but from what I could gather, Alma, the creepy little F.E.A.R mainstay, has become pregnant for whatever reason, and the main character, the Point Man" and his brother Paxton Fettel
date: who was killed in F.E.A.R 1 and who has somehow returned
recommended: have to find her and... well
hoursPlayed: Fettel wants to eat the child and Point Man wants to destroy it. That's as much as I could gather.\n\nThe game takes about 6 to 7 hours to beat
voteText: though this is somewhat artificially extended by the game's difficulty. I was playing on "Commando" (Normal) difficulty
helpfulPercent: and some areas of the game were heavily confusing and others were incredibly difficult
votesHelpful: particularly one section where I had to defeat a massive mech which could kill me in a few shots and tear any cover you might choose to use to pieces
votesTotal: and also another where I was attacked by TWO of the most annoying enemy in the game
votesFunny: which needless to say was frustrating.\n\nTo summarise

reviewText: This game wasn't actually made by Monolith; it was developed by Day One Studios, the studio that was previously only responsible for making the console ports of FEAR 1 and its expansions. It shows, in a lot of ways. The levels are much more linear, you're limited to two weapons, and the graphics are arguably worse than FEAR 2's and maybe even FEAR 1's. The story is barely coherent at best (which isn't helped by the fact that despite FEAR 3 having actual cutscenes, Pointman is still a silent protagonist who only communicates through furiously scrunching his eyebrows), and you don't even get a clear goal or an idea of where you're actually going until around halfway through the game's 4 hour campaign. The only aspect of the game that's anything interesting is the co-op system, in which the two players are cooperating but still loosely competing against each other to decide which ending they get, which works a lot better than it does in games that somehow manage to be even worse than this one like Call of Juarez: The Cartel. And that's a good thing, because the only way I can recommend even considering playing this game is if you have a friend to play it with, though even then it's only a loose recommendation since this game is really only that fun under the any game is fun with a friend" rule. This game barely has enough content to be a hard sell if it were priced at $10 or $15 like the first two games are
date: but at $20 it's absolutely not worth picking up unless you just really want to suffer through an evening with a friend and have expended all other available options."

reviewText: FEAR 3 Was unlike any of the other FEAR Games but that was good, in where it become more of a FPS THan a Horror game but you still get that scary feeling when exploring the atmosphere I've bought this on Xbox and PC And I'm still not dissapointed but it is a shame the Multiplayer has gone inacitve, but there are still groups andp eople that will paly with you on it what I'm trying to say is F.E.A.R 3 is a misunderstood game, infact it's a great game that deserves alot of credit. I haven't experienced one glitch or bug and I've played through the campaign twice the point is it's been years and my hopes of FEAR 4 Have sadly come to an end, I really hope one day FEAR 4 May come true but the Developers will need as much support as they can get, Overall this is how I'm gonna end my review, FEAR 3 Was a great game, great design, development and the Setting even sometimes got me a little depressed on the inside which made it all the more better. Great game, like all the FEARs would definately reccomend

reviewText: I love this game and the entire series in general. If you like FPS, Horror, and Gore you should give this a shot. It has a solid FPS feel and being able to play Fettle gives it a new twist. I am playing backwards through the Fear series but it is really entertaining. I think it needs an update though to give Fettle more bonuses because Pointman seems to always out score him no matter what you do.\n\nI haven't counted but I believe it's because Pointman has more opportunities to score points and Fettle has to posses a body to even compete. Fettle is really fun to play just don't count on getting the ending you want based on Fettle due to the unbalance. Played through COOP with a friend over seas and the network code was flawless. Highly recomend for a good time just don't try and compete for favorite son, it's biased.

reviewText:
I have a lot of gripes with where Day 1 Studios went with the story and tone, but the gameplay of F.E.A.R. 3 is as fun as the series has ever been. F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 are much more well-rounded and sensibly designed, but F.E.A.R. 3 does have co-op. Yes, it does have co-op. Designing the campaign with co-op in mind is probably the main culprit for why F.E.A.R. 3's story/campaign isn't quite as great as the other two's. It ends weird and kind of anti-climactically too. But, it does have co-op.

The combat is just about as deliciously good as the other games in the series though, so despite its odd disappointments in terms of how it concluded the series, it should still be a fun romp for anyone who liked the other F.E.A.R. games. It's mostly the same in that regard, although with rank challenges (a sort of points system) and noticeably less scary. Playing as Paxton Fettel is also a cool spin on things that adds replayability. And the rank challenges (which is in all modes) add an extra layer of fun.

Also, Alma's just ugly in this one... :(

reviewText: Much more satisfying ending if you let your character shotgun himself in the face early in the game. Also probably the worst of the Fear games. FEAR 3 takes the first two games, and strips it of its soul, then makes you do several repeatative fights with Doctor Manhattan cosplayers. I don't want to ruin the ending, but lets just say towards the end it just tells anyone who played FEAR 2 to go ♥♥♥♥ themselves, cause we ain't havin none of that plot ♥♥♥♥ up in here. Then the story derails off like a school bus full of children into a void where story and character build up should be. Funny thing is, took me 6 hours to complete Fear 2, and 4 hours to beat FEAR 3, but it felt so much longer because of how dragged out the tedious fights were with Doctor Manhattans fan club.

reviewText:
Well, a great dissapointment has befallen me within the first 10 minutes of playing this game.

I was a huge fan of F.E.A.R. , F.E.A.R. Extraction Point,  F.E.A.R. Perseus Mandate, and knowing how sequels often get dilluted in the development process, I was surprised to see that F.E.A.R. 2 is just as good as the original with actual improvements to the lighting, sound, and gameplay that don't detriment the trademark ambience of the classic F.E.A.R., which makes sense because the entire franchise up to this point was developed by Monolith as a competitive PC market shooter.

Unfortunately,   F.E.A.R. 3 offers none of this.   Because it's a blatant console port.   The lighting is absolutely horrid.  There's some ridiculous grainy mist all over the place which apparently  serves to dress up the fact that the architecture and lighting are completely inadequate for a game in this series, and why is that?  Because it was developed for underpowered fanboy consoles.  F.E.A.R. 1 had better graphics than this, because it was developed for PCs that came out BEFORE PS3, and XBOX 360, which strongly underlines the fact of how pathetic consoles and their games are.  The storyline is completely thrown out the window on this one too. There's no explanation of how Pointman ended up in a prison cell, but we're supposed to be pacified by the appearance of a badly animated cartoon-like Fettel with a  bullet which miraculously stopped in a crater on his forehead. Odd, because I distinctly remember blowing his brains completely out in F.E.A.R. Is this a way to help the clueless console fanboys who didn't play the first two F.E.A.R. games figure out that Fettel was killed by a gunshot to the head and Pointman did it?  Apparently so.  But let's not neglect to mention that the voiceovers for the replica soldiers is equally as disconcerting.  They talk like normal people.   They are not normal people.  As we learned in F.E.A.R. 2 these Replica soldiers under their masks are facially disfigured cheap human clones with little education or vocal skill, and their voice should be gruffy, low and borderline animalistic.  In F.E.A.R. 3 they talk like professional sports announcers at the International Table Tennis Tournament. When you shoot them, you get a yellow hit marker, and if you squint really hard you might see a tinge of red blood. Where is the gore?  But within 10 minutes you'll also be able to figure out that the introduction of Alma in this game is about as frightening as an angry poodle. Another opportunity wasted.  The use of music in the game is done poorly, and the music itself is completely uninspiring.  Another opportunity wasted. Go into settings.  That's right, auto-aim is on by default, because this is a console port.  All this culminates into F.E.A.R. 3 being a total let down and downright disgrace to what is otherwise a legendary franchise loved by many. When will game publishers learn to stop destroying great concepts in the name of wider market audiences and temporary profit gains?  WB clearly took a page from the EA and Activision book on F.E.A.R. 3 and it's no surprise we'll never see another real F.E.A.R. game again...

reviewText: I didn't connect in any way with any of the F.E.A.R. games.  Especially this third game.  And for the icing on the cake, the last two levels were among the most disappointing levels in any game I've ever played.\n\nIf there is anything good I can say about the series is that the combat, even minus the slo-mo, was still fun and was what kept me going throughout.

reviewText:
FEAR3 plays like if Half-life 2 and CoD had a ugly child,
who then had a child with a buggy 90s FPS.
It's got it all: Ominscent AI, Magic Bullets, Heisenberg's Walls,
Impassable Pebbles, Feathery Hit Boxes... you name it.
That's not to say it cannot be fun, but what a sad way
to end this franchise.

If you're thinking of getting this one, may I suggest you
buy Fear2 instead?  The first in the series is very good of course,
but it doesn't run well on modern systems, and by modern I mean
post-2009ish.

reviewText:
Unlike seemingly every other reviewer, I actually much preferred this game to FEAR2 (it's been so long since I played the first FEAR I can't compare them).  If you forget about the horror element, what you have here is an extremely accomplished shooter - cover system is great, slo-mo works well, enemy AI is good.  The horror elements are basically limited to lots of melee-type characters that try and swarm you.  Although the warehouse/shop level did doa  pretty good job of buidling suspense before the actual bad guys turned up.

There is a bit of replay value to be had here as well, you can replay the game as the murderous ghost once you've completed a level as point-man.  I did a couple of levels with Fettel before I decided that while being novel, that character didn't add enough for me to replay the same story with a different set of abilities - those with more time on their hands may well feel differently.

Summary: forget the FEAR back story and enjoy a polished shooter.

reviewText: When I played F.E.A.R. (First Encounter Assult Recon), I was thrilled and driven into the story. The expansions were just as good. Then FEAR 2 came along. Graphically, it was a woe and gameplay had its' moments. But I found myself most shocked and not as content with the ending. Expansion for FEAR 2 was rather short, but made FEAR 3 possible. Too easy, nontheless. Then came FEAR 3. Play with yourself, play Co-Op, or hop into some intense multiplayer modes. For me, overall, I prefere survivals. The campaign was kinda short and the ending just didn't quite fit in with what I hoped to see in a conclusion. After all is said and done, I found myself wanting to go back to the first game+ expansions. Graphics isn't everything. Needless to say, it was a part of the series and wasn't horrible.

I suggest playing the story in Co-op your first time, and then playing it again on Insane (The fourth difficulty after you beat the game) reversing roles between Point-Man and Fettel, depending on which one you played your first time, and have a different experience, even though the  Then you can play F*cking Run and Contractions, the other Coop modes. And even after THAT you can play Soul King and Soul Survivor, which are the competitive ones.

One thing that does suck, are the graphics, some levels just look generic, in the beginning there's one that looks like you're in Brazil's favelas, but the textures just suck, you can notice it in (for example) some enemies that behave like zombies with melee weapons in their hands.

I'd say it deserves an 8.3 (Yeah, that specific)

reviewText:
This game gets an unfair bad wrap. Long story short; is it as good as the first two? No. But is it a bad game? Also no. The issue arises from the fact that F.E.A .R 3 tries to be an entirely different genre of shooter from the previous two games, and while this can and has alienated some fans I think it’s unfair to call it a bad game if taken on its own merits. No it isn’t the best game in the series, but it’s far from a sub-par game if viewed at alone.

The previous two relied heavily on narrative and while neither was truly scary they did an admirable job of crafting a permeable atmosphere of the supernatural. The third game on the other hand goes in very heavy-handed with the action and mostly relies on flickering lights and ghostly apparitions as its one sole link to suggest it’s actually trying to be a horror game at all. There are a few segments (the third mission comes to mind) where it seems like a totally different team took over and the game steps into the overboard gore and insanity of the previous two games but these are unfortunately short-lived and not evocative of the whole experience. Additionally most of the story is reserved for cut-scenes tacked on to the start and end of missions with most of mid-mission exposition from the previous entries missing

And don’t get me wrong these are real negatives. That said the gunplay on offer here is very streamlined and of a high quality, the environments while not of a superb graphical level are very well crafted and have a lot of details, and I’m a big fan of how they handled “leveling up” to give you small benefits over the previous games “Boosters” (which had you combing each environment or more likely running off to a FAQ).  Additionally a system in which you gain points based on accomplishing tasks like killing enemies with a certain weapon, taking cover, or using slo-mo a certain amount of time are another factor that removes the horror out of the game, and yet at the same time I find it hard to fault the system as it’s genuinely fun to try and get the highest score you can. The focus of the game on co-op seems very misplaced for the series but the fit the actual game itself.

All-in-all this is a perfectly serviceable shooter that has more choice and depth than the average modern military shooter. It’s unfortunate that it steps so far away from its lineage and I can see why people take issue with this fact. But if you stop trying to lament how different it is at every step you’ll still find a perfectly fun and working package here.

reviewText:
I hate console games. The devs who have taken a great franchise and destroyed it by porting this crappy colsole over to PC. Let me list just a few of the problems.
1. There is no save. They've repalced it with a checkpoint system where you have to replay over and over.
2. No leaning. How are you expected to sneak in a game with multiple enemies and not be able to lean to take a shot.
3. It crashes. Constantly. The longest I've been able to play it has been 20 mins before it freezes the system. I've tried the workaround of forcing DX9 and it still crashes. Tried lowering the AA on my graphics card. Same thing.
4. 2 weapons?? Really! What the cr@p is that about? And a max of 175 rounds for a machinegun?
This game is total trash and not worth even the $10 I paid for it. I got a refund from Amazon and promptly deleted this off my system.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 3 is a fantastic game trapped inside a series which developed most of its inertia from great gameplay. The game takes on a new form, almost entirely, giving the player much more room and ability with weapons, reflexes and cover shooting; the game is promiscuous about enemy design and strategy, giving a lot of the momentum of the fights away to who has the bigger gun--a lot like Halo 3, however in Halo 3, Brutes attack you without necessary consent from superiors, in F.E.A.R.3, some enemies won't be as aggressive if you are faced with a mech, or a soldier with greater weaponry. The A.I. in this game pales very clearly in comparison to the original. Most enemies run right at you, knowing you have an advantage in accuracy and dexterity. The game tries to compensate for this by throwing more enemies at you, in bigger and burlier fashion, though, your reflex mode (now almost Godmode), gives you complete superiority in nearly every situation the game offers.

This game wraps up the Armacham story and hastily. Something about Paxton Fettel living on in your psyche, due to Alma's pervasive ability and extrasennsory ability, allowing you direct psychic link with Fettel and some dead clone soldiers. Knowing that, it seems like a very indirect way to tie up a story about encountering a hellish creature, given that Fettel was the primary antagonist of the original game up until the end, and Harlan Wade was your antithesis, it would have made more sense to undermine the future of Alma, and give her a much desired explication, of her past, who she possessed and how she survived so long, giving necessary closure to a series that basically, revolved around her.

The game is gorgeous, parallel to games like Left for Dead 2, and Tribes Ascend. There's a great attention to detail and even better presentation, if you're up for that sort of thing but this game is no Metro 2033.

As a sequel, this game falls flat on its face. As a game, it's amazing and should be played by anyone who enjoys Call of Duty, Serious Sam or any FPS that's mildly hectic. A must play for F.E.A.R. fans, to figure out what exactly makes the original games so good.

reviewText: Why am I reviewing this with only 3 hours of gameplay in (at this time)? Because I pirated it, and I bought this on sale for eight bucks which is roughly what I'd say this was worth. The graphics are pretty dated, the physics are very buggy, and the enviorments are insanly linear. Most of the fear is gone with only a few sections in the very beginning which were filled with pop out scares. The leveling system is dumb and god help me it feels like I have tunnel vision. This game makes you feel like you have a fov of 30. Fettel (the unlockable character) is basically a silly rehash of the main character with little added that's worthwhile. The story is cliche, dull, and feels irrelevant to the rest of the game. Who are these people? Why is she helping me? I only see them once the entire game? I will say, the action in the game is pretty decent and the game can be fun at times, but overall this game is a consolized let down. 6/10.

reviewText: Every FEAR game has been a step backward from the one before it. FEAR 3 brings some coop to the table through 2-sided mission design (play as Point Man or unlock/visit-another's-game as the ghostly Fettle) at the cost of extremely linear environments and dumb enemies. Any pretext of horror is gone, replaced by a mix of interesting scary" environments and corridor-shooting. The game itself is WAY TOO SHORT (6 hrs).\n\nHowever
date: I still recommend FEAR 3 for two reasons: it finishes the "story" of the series and features first-person cover mechanics. I can't think of any other shooter that offers first-person cover on PC
recommended: and it's an interesting if limiting design choice. The shooting is also decent
hoursPlayed: although the gun models are too big (I usually don't care about that sort of thing).\n\nIf you want to see the end of this sadly reduced series
voteText: just get the game."

Apparently after F.E.A.R. 2, Alma somehow got knocked up AGAIN and is having a third f*cking demon child (even though she's dead?)...

It just makes NO sense, the only thing thats fun is the gameplay/co-op but the boss battles and extremely hard gameplay RUIN this piece of sh*t just like 2 did.

Meh, good luck.

5/10

reviewText: Why am I reviewing this with only 3 hours of gameplay in (at this time)? Because I pirated it, and I bought this on sale for eight bucks which is roughly what I'd say this was worth. The graphics are pretty dated, the physics are very buggy, and the enviorments are insanly linear. Most of the fear is gone with only a few sections in the very beginning which were filled with pop out scares. The leveling system is dumb and god help me it feels like I have tunnel vision. This game makes you feel like you have a fov of 30. Fettel (the unlockable character) is basically a silly rehash of the main character with little added that's worthwhile. The story is cliche, dull, and feels irrelevant to the rest of the game. Who are these people? Why is she helping me? I only see them once the entire game? I will say, the action in the game is pretty decent and the game can be fun at times, but overall this game is a consolized let down. 6/10.

reviewText:
There are a few good and bad points to this game as listed.

Pros:
1) It ties up the lose ends of the story.
2) Most of it only makes sence if you played through the first 2 games.
3) Good over all gameplay (By that I mean it is fun).

Cons:
1) It is not any where near Horror" any more
date:
In fact most of the "scare effects" you can easly miss if you like to watch your back and make sure you don't get shot in it.
2) Most of it only makes sence if you played through the first 2 games.
3) It took a solid 1P FPS Horror and added leaderboards to the campain.
4) The only way to play Fettel is to "Replay" a single mission. You can't play as him for the whole campain? Why add a char and lock it out as they do?

Overall it's good if you played the first 2
recommended: if for nothing else but some "closure"."

reviewText:
FEAR3 isn't meant to be played Solo. If you have a friend you can CO-OP with this is a brilliant game. I played as Fetal on my play through and the different tactics opened up to me made a very good impression on me.

The Campaign is not long which kind of works as a CO-OP game I think at one stage we will swap over and I'll play Point Man and will be a differen't experience. Between the mechs and the horror mechanics I think this is a solid co-op game but I imagine it would not of been as fun single player.
As Fetal I was able to capture and hold enemies for Point Man to kill, Possess Snipers at the other end of the killzone and then between us take out everyone in the middle. Being bound to Pointman was limmiting but that mechanic made it more interesting like I had to be within range of him to exist.

reviewText:
SP Review
Difficulty Played on: Fearless (Hard)

FEAR 3 is a solid action game. It has times were the atmosphere is quite disturbing, but it is nowhere near as scary as the original. For those of you who have completed the original and all its expansions, this will be kind of a rehash of the 3rd expansion Perseus Mandate, only instead of fighting the merc group Nightcrawlers, you are fighting ATC corporate commandos. The story is of course different and like Project Origin, FEAR 3 ignores the original expansions  (Jin is still alive and such, Jankowski is not mentioned, but strangely your FEAR CO is still dead as he was in the Extraction Point Expansion)   You play as the Point Man from the original FEAR, and you fight Armacham as they struggle to cover up everything that went wrong in Fairpoint. You travel alongside your psychotic brother Paxton Fettel as you try to stop your mother Alma. Like I said, the game is a very solid action game, but it feels similar to many modern FPS shooters to were it feels like a shooting gallery. Enemies come at predictable patterns and can be easily outflanked and outmanuevered. You get rank ups for completing different challenges such as time spent in bullet time, weapon kills, and performing various manuever or enviromental kills. For each rank, you get a bonus in the form of more ammo, more health, etc. There are soul links hidden throughout the levels as well as dolls to get you additional XP. Finding them is not to difficult if you take the time to look around, but it kind of breaks up the actions a bit. This is similar to the original FEAR power-up system were you find health and reflex boosters.

There are times in the game were it pulls you out of the action to deal with various paranormal entities in the game (The Creep being a noteable one). I did not find this scary as much as annoying getting routinely cheapshotted in a random part of the level. This does not serve to build much atmosphere as the monster itself is not to frightening and dampens the flow of gameplay IMO. There are some nice scary moments particularly in interval 3-5 when you go back to Fairpoint. The ambience here is great and the disturbing denizens bring back memories of the psychos from the Condemned series. These were my favorite parts of the game by far. Toward the ending intervals... The action became more tedious then rewarding. Using Power Armor was fun when it was first introduced, but it becomes fustrating during the Bridge interval. I should also point out that you cannot initially play as Paxton Fettel and can only play as him if you beat an interval as the Point Man. Paxton Fettel can suspend, possess, or use his psychic powers in a variety of cool ways, which does add something new to the game. There are two endings depending on who you beat the game with obviously, and Paxton Fettel's abilities do warrant a second playthrough. If you do play CO-OP through the whole game, whoever has the highest score determines the ending adding some competative play to CO-OP.

Overall, the SP was fun and despite its hiccups was solid. The story wrapped up kind of weak and left me somewhat confused regarding the future of the series as well as other questions such as  why did Alma die after giving birth to her child, and why would she even consider Point Man a choice to be her successor. Paxon Fettel seemed to share her  goals and had a special link with her mother growing up. I also felt that it was a missed opportunity to not fight Paxton let alone Alma instead of Harlan Wade (who died in the first game). Alma has become quite an iconic horror figure, and it is a shame she went out with such a dull roar given how she laid waste to any and all who stood in her way  All in all, story aside, the game is definately fun and disturbing. Wait for a sale and pick it up.

SP Score: 7.8/10

Pros
- Good gunplay
- Great Atmosphere in some levels
- Solid action game
- Phase Commanders are a nice addition to the opposing force
- Rank Up System is fun for completionists or people who like challenges
- Multiple endings and Characters

Cons
- Becomes repetative
- ATC soldiers aren't as interesting or threatening as the Replica Forces
- Not as impressive of an arsenal compared to the previous titles
- Some ingame events break up the action and can become fustrating
- Though disturbing and creepy, the story is rather weak and the wrap up was phoned in
- Monsters are nowhere near as disturbing or creepy as the original FEAR games
- Missed opportunity: ending boss battle

reviewText:
Lets start this review with the truth. FEAR 3 is not a FEAR game at all and rather its a generic FPS. It was devd by Day 1 Studios, who handled the porting of FEAR 1 to PS3 and 360 (I originally played the PS3 version and have to say if memory serves it was a fine port that stayed true to the original game) and some games that were deemed mediocre when they came out and no one has ever talked about them since. So it makes sense that this game isn't a FEAR game aside from the name.

The story is based off of what has come about from the first two games but unlike the spooky and mysterious tone of the first two games and especially the first this one just starts off goofy and borderline stupid. Something you get from a comic...book....http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Niles ....whoever hired this guy to write a story while looking at his resume is undeserving of the job they had at the time. I mean look at this guy, he wears facial hair and dresses like hes 30 or more years younger than he is and it looks terrible. He just looks like a manchild or something. Comic book stories are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, so now the FEAR story line at 3 is goofy and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like a comic book. 2 wasn't terribly great in anyway but 3 is just so so much worse especially story wise. Paxton Fettel is back and he is a ghost who helps you....this is literally the reason I don't read comic books. He dousn't help you like a beneficial all knowing god either, he just grabs you while your drowning and pulls you to safety kind of help. Steve Niles, if I ever end up near you...my fist requires a connection to your face.

Gameplay wise its actually not fun at all. Its a generic fps so you just go through the motions of killing emotionless brainless AI enemies that don't follow any of the logic rules that made 1 so good. Flanking enemies dousn't do much when they are watching you through walls or just snap to you. Ammo is rare enough as to create a major annoyance and considering enemies soak up hits you find yourself with less than a magazine of ammo most the time. Its just like every other generic FPS game you played than forgot about and never cared about again. Enemies don't react quite enough to make it feel like your doing anything to them when you shoot them and shooting in general dousn't feel terribly good. The choice of weapons is very limited aswell, which in past games and especially in 1 wasn't much of a problem since shooting and all that felt excellent and still do. I was gonna throw in a COD joke since thats so trendy these days but honestly, this is more generic and worse than COD.

Graphics are dated compared to the original or even 2. Overly demanding without a reason on higher settings. Its blurry diarhea in general. Sound is nothing special either, meh.

Presentation wise the game comes off as if it was meant for multiplayer, I feel thats where it would shine in COOP where you and a bro arn't really paying much attention to the game itself. But honestly the way its all setup gameplay wise where one player is Paxton and the other gets the gun is really boring for one player or maybe both. Its just a crappy game. I want to call it ♥♥♥♥ but honestly its not really quite that bad. Its just generic and not worth much to me. It shouldn't be a FEAR game at all as its obvious they just wanted to use the name to bag bucks and screw the long term possible profits from future games.

Everything from the old FEAR is here, but its not quite the same. Its like they looked at Fear 2 and tried to make it even more generic and casualised than 2. So now that makes Fear 3 miles away from Fear 1 and in the wrong direction with one shoe and no pants. Its just not a good FEAR game and a generic FPS in general. So basically its ♥♥♥♥, but its not really ♥♥♥♥ because you can't tell if its ♥♥♥♥ because you will probably just get bored in an hour and just quit so you will never know if its really ♥♥♥♥ or just boring as watching trees grow in slow motion.

reviewText:
3 OUT OF 5. recommend.but not very enthusiastically, and NOT for full price.
I really liked the first games, and the add-on packs. I was disappointed by this one.
Definitely not up to the usual F.E.A.R level.  I don't like losing weapons after almost every interlude. , Also weapons have stupidly low levels of max ammunition. I wouldnt go into combat with only 150 rounds in my primary weapon, and I died quite a few times scrambling to try to find another weapon that had ammo.
The rendering isnt the most accurate. By which I mean you can be behind a barricade, and since this primitive game doesnt allow the lean feature, the only way to shoot from cover is to try to shoot over or expose your whole body shooting around.  If the center of a sandbag barricade is 4' high and the sides are 3' high, you cant shoot over the sides unless you aim higher than the center. You can SEE but you can't shoot. Also if throwing a grenade, the trajectory is as if you're tossing from your testicular level. I never carried 'nades by my 'nads. .
The worst part is the new Captain?" who somehow craps out enemies relentlessly so that you need to try to kill him (and he takes a lot of killing)
date: while dealing with attackers spawning from all around you.  THen at one point when you're low on ammo two of them spawn. They can appear anywhere
hoursPlayed: so you die over and over.\nSince they've gone the ever-popular console route
voteText: there is no way to save manually so you'll have to replay over and over to get past the areas where the enemy keeps respawning 5 and 6 at a time. One other criticism. When mapping keys
helpfulPercent: you cant reuse keys for different functions if in a mech suit or on foot. So you have to try to find keys you can reach easily and remember what they are
votesHelpful: or remap every time you switch from armor to foot. Yes
votesTotal: it's a minor criticism
votesFunny: but most good games have a separation between vehicle key mappings and on-foot key mappings since you obviously wont be doing the same actions in a vehicle as you would on foot.\nThis isn't the worst game ever as some have said
commentsCount: it's just not fun enough to put up with the negatives. When the bogus (I"d use something else that has B and S in it) level got too high
column16: I just stopped playing. I'll wait before buying for any future "Day 1 Studios' games
column17: checking online for HONEST reviews and not reading reviews posted by the seller.\nTWO GOOD THINGS: the challenges to level up added in single player are a pretty cool feature
column18: . Even better
column19: and the reason for the third start
column20: is that the long cutscenes in between levels ARE SKIPPABLE! (pay attention Fart Cry duhvelopers).\nNOTE: I didn't try multiplayer

reviewText: TAKE ON THE ROLE OF Point Man
date:
A MUTE, CONSTANTLY EXTREMELY ANGRY BROTHER OF A GUY WHO LOOKS DISTURBINGLY LIKE NICOLAS CAGE. AS YOU MOVE FROM ONE GENERIC LEVEL TO THE NEXT, YOU MAY FIND YOURSELF OCCASIONALLY STOPPING MIDGAME TO THINK ABOUT HOW LITTLE SENSE THE STORY NOW MAKES, COMPARED TO FEAR 1 AND 2, WHICH WERE BOTH OKAY. FIGHT YOUR WAY THROUGH HORDES OF DEMONS, HOMELESS PEOPLE, (I THINK THEY'RE HOMELESS? I HONESTLY DON'T KNOW. THEY TAKE A LOT OF DAMAGE AND FOR SOME REASON ONLY SHOW UP FOR LIKE, ONE LEVEL. THE STORY NEVER REALLY CLEARS UP WHO THEY ARE, BUT IT DOESN'T CLEAR UP A LOT OF THINGS.) AND THE GUYS THAT YOU WERE WORKING FOR IN THE FIRST FEAR GAME BECAUSE, SCREW PROPER STORYTELLING, RIGHT?

OH, AND I HOPE YOU DIDN'T PLAY EXTRACTION POINT FOR FEAR 1, BECAUSE THROW EVERYTHING THAT HAPPENED IN THAT OUT THE WINDOW. EXCEPT FOR YOU AND NICOLAS CAGE TEAMING UP. AND HOLIDAY DYING. AND ARMACHAM THINKING THAT YOU TURNED ON THEM. THAT'S RIGHT, FOLKS, JIN IS STILL ALIVE, EVEN THOUGH YOU WATCH HER GET ♥♥♥♥ING MERKED IN EXTRACTION POINT.
SO ANYWAYS: YOU AND NICOLAS CAGE ARE NOW BROS, AND YOU TWO GO AROUND KILLING STUFF. AND THINGS. THINGS THAT ARE NEVER REALLY EXPLAINED IN THE STORY. LIKE HOMELESS PEOPLE. YOU START THE GAME OFF IN A PRISON LIKE ANY GOOD SKYRIM GAME, AND FOR SOME REASON YOU HAVE A KNIFE IN YOUR CELL. YOU START OFF WITH A KNIFE. YOU ARE HOLDING A KNIFE IN YOUR PRISON CELL. AM I THE ONLY PERSON WHO NOTICED THIS?
ANYWAYS. YOU FIND OUT THAT JIN IS STILL ALIVE, EVEN THOUGH SHE OBVIOUSLY DIED IN FEAR 1. SO YOU AND PAXTEENI FATALLOONEY SET OUT TO FIND HER. AND YOU DO. AND SHE LIVES, I THINK. AND THEN YOU BECOME A FATHER, AND NICOLAS CAGE GETS DOMED BY YOU.
OH, AND IF YOU PLAYED FEAR 2, BECKETT GETS BLOWN INTO NOTHING BY (YOU GUESSED IT!) THE CAGESTER.
THERE YOU GO, I JUST SAVED YOU FROM LIKE, FOUR HOURS OF THE MOST UNENJOYABLE CONCLUSION TO ANY VIDEOGAME TRILOGY, EVER.
SERIOUSLY, DON'T BUY THIS GAME.

I MEAN, ON THE BRIGHT SIDE, ALMA LOOKS KINDA HOT AT THE END OF THE GAME, IN A WEIRD YOU'RE-MY-MOM-WHO-IS-ALSO-CURRENTLY-GIVING-BIRTH-AND-COVERED-IN-BLOOD" SORT OF WAY."

reviewText:
Just like most of the other F.E.A.R games, the single player missions isn't long. Give it some hours and its over, but all the Intervals (maps) are re-playable since you will now be able to play as both Pointman and Fettel.

Pointman with his original slowmotion ability and Fettel with his ability to temporarly take over bodies wich can make him very powerful. Its also possible to play the campaign with a friend. One as Pointman, one as Fettel.

There are also several multiplayer mods such as Soul survivor" "Soul king" F***ing run" and "Contractions". All of them playable with 3 other players and even new characters not found in either single player or the earlier games.

Something unique with this game are the challanges. You can complete challanges and gain points EVERY time you play a single / coop map. Even if you have completed the challanges before. You can also search and find Alma dolls ;).

It do have some bugs
date: and you can't mute players in coop

reviewText: The storyline in this game dosen't make a whole lot of sense in context with fear 1 and 2. The reveal that Alma is pointman's mother in fear 3 seems to cheapen the scares in fear 1 since you now know she is your mother and dosent want to hurt her own son. It also makes no sense that spooky pants cannibal Paxton Fettel would help pointman all of a sudden after being killed by him in Extraction Point. For the first time ever in a fear game you can only carrry two weapons.. In fear 1 you could carry 3 weapons and in fear 2 you could carry 4. Why regress back to two weapons? You miss out on all the fun guns since the ammo for them is so rare they arnt worth picking up. There are no longer any competitive multiplayer modes like deathmatch or capture the flag, however i'll admit the co-op is a lot of fun. F.3.A.R. isn't a bad game, it's just a bad F.E.A.R. game. Hopefully one day we will get Fear 4 and possibly play as Alma's new baby or another original character.

reviewText:
FEAR 3 is particular in its way. Its most unusual feature consists in the fact that there's actually no fear - just anger, and irritation, and tiredness. It's not a thriller anymore - just a shooter. It still bears certain resemblance to Crysis, but I'd say that the latter is more 'paranormal' when compared to this certain game. And the bosses. sure, like in good old times. Damn, I hate bosses, really. (That was a reason why I liked the original FEAR, for instance.)
What's on the positive side of it? Well, that's fine graphics, some new battle enhancements (such as the possibility to take cover behind certain objects and shoot from your hideout - previous FEARs lacked that function), and the gameplay fork that lets you play either with Pointman or with Fettel. And self-restoring health, yes.
What's negative? Simplification, the common disease found in modern games. FEAR and (to some extent) FEAR 2 were more interesting; they were not merely about shooting people, there was room for investigation, for some exploration, and for some mystery. Now that's more trivial: here are some Armacham troops, here are you, you must kill them all and advance further. The same enemies, the same weapons... etc.
My verdict - good, but not great. Worth giving a try, though.

reviewText:
After finishing FEAR with expansions and FEAR 2, I expected another decent game. Shortly it came out that this game is not what i've expected.

First of all, developers changed health system to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one which relies on hiding on covers after you receive damage. Now you can easily hide behind cover after taking many shots unlike it was in previous games.

Secondly in previous games difficulty level was high, now before we finish game it is not possible te set highest level. Tell me why? When you are experienced player you dont want to play game many times.

Thirdly, developers included some kind off collectibles - soldiers to sync. Number of collected has influence on score after finishing level, but it doesn't mean any casualties, so why to find all? I don't have any idea.

Another one new thing in series is level, so when you get higher level you get possibility to have more ammo and last longer in slow-mo. Unfortunately you dont have now to find any hidden items.

To sump up this part of series sucks, if you liked previous episodes you probably wont like this one. Unfortunately, this is more CoD like game than FEAR. For me 4 out of 10.

reviewText:
I liked the game much better than I thought I would given the mixed reviews. It was quite a lot of fun overall even if the scares are definitely getting more than long in the tooth. Alma never does anything so it's only mildly creepy at best when she makes an appearance but never really scary.

So if we ignore the almost non-existent horror elements and just focus on the shooter mechanics, then we're still left with a competent game in the FPS genre. The gun gameplay is great, the choice of weapons is good and it's just good fun mowing down the soldiers in all sorts of ways, collecting achievements and scores along the way which add a motivating extra reward layer.
The AI is quite smart and aggressive at times which makes the game challenging pretty often (Commando difficulty for me). There were a couple parts where I was ready to smash something (especially a certain gate that needed to be open in a late game level where you got swamped with monsters - by the way: not an endless spawn as written in some guides... you can kill them all by hiding behind the trash container where they can't reach you... a few more will spawn once you push the button on the other side but you can easily deal with those few until the gate is down far enough for no more to be able to pass through).

Anyway, my only gripes would be the way the levels are designed. Doors/gates/etc. just close behind you so the levels are very segmented and you can never backtrack for e.g. searching for a missed reward (e.g. Alma doll). On the other hand there is also very little room for exploration which would be another negative. This is a corridor shooter through and through. Thirdly, no quick save is kinda lame and sometimes the checkpoint saves are not spaced/placed ideally.
And finally some of the boss fights (not the final one but the in-between ones) are pretty annoyingly hard.

Overall it is a fun shooter though with a decent plot that motivates you to keep going, even more so if you know the story of F.E.A.R 1 + 2 plus expansions. The shooter mechanics are fun and it's also fun to collect the um... collectibles and achievements. It was NOT fun enough to motivate me to replay as Fettel (I only finished the game as Pointman) but I would definitely recommend anyone to give this game a try, especially now that it should be available for just a few bucks. It's quite a bit better than the Metacritic average would lead you to believe. It would deserve a low-ish 8x average. Thumbs up.

reviewText: It's a decent shooter, but for me it really took the Fear out of F.E.A.R; fans of the series will surely be dissapointed in the lack of tension or atmosphere, and the story is far too shallow to warrant any investment. The gunplay is solid, but suffers from a lack of enemy type; there's only one supernatural enemy type, and the soldier classes are few and unoriginal. There are a few randomized jump scares that might get you here and there, but overall its not scary; it's built too much like a straight action game. The co-op is only as entertaining as the friend you're playing with, and it only serves to further detract from what little tension there was to begin with. As a huge fan of F.E.A.R. 1 and 2, I have to give this oe a thumbs down :(

reviewText: FEAR 3 is heavily dependent on knowing what happened in the previous games. If you haven't played the first two, you'll be pretty confused as to who these characters are and what exactly has happened. If you have played and enjoyed the first two, you'll be happy to hear that FEAR 3 is more of the same: excellent gameplay with a unique atmosphere. BUT this is an arcade action game with the horror all drained out, so while I enjoyed it the tone is super different from the first two.

reviewText: Let me just begin to say that I love the F.E.A.R. series but any fan of it knew that it was going downhill after the second game so its your own fault for expecting this game to be like the original. The actual fear factor and feel of the original games is not really there anymore. Granted some parts were pretty scary but seeing Alma didn't really scare me like it used to. It was more like looking at her in a zoo where she pops up and you get excited to see her as oppose to not wanting to  her to jump scare you or the horrible stuff she does to to alter the reality around you. This game is great as a FPS shooter game though. The action is pretty good and theres no stupid level of difficulty where you get frustrated and dont want to continue. All in all I have to give it a positive rating due to it being a decent shooter, but it doesnt really deserve to be a part of the F.E.A.R. franchise. If you can look past that then you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R 3 does not feel like like a F.E.A.R game, compared to the previous two titles this game has very little scary factor in it, there is too much action & the storyline is plain old awful, it is a big let down to F.E.A.R fans.

The gameplay is okay, it has its elements from the previous titles, the atmosphere from creepy is few and far between, Alma looks a bit too cartoony in my opinion, I actually laughed the first time I saw her (compared to previous titles), not only that but Beckett's (F.E.A.R 2) death is plain old bland & unecessary.

Overall F.E.A.R 3 is a decent game to play, but story wise its awful & doesn't feel like a F.E.A.R game, not worth picking up if you have played the previous two unless your curious to do so.

*Note, the game is short also, only took me about 3-4 hours to beat, unlike the previous F.E.A.R's this game is tiny, 4 GB... compared to F.E.A.R 2 (14 GB) & F.E.A.R 1 (12GB).

reviewText:
I've always been a fan of the Fear games. While their gameplay wasn't the best, it was still highly entertaining and had just enough horror to keep me shaking in my booties.

Fear 3 takes a step into a deep dark part of the gaming world, co-op. For a Horror game, co-op ultimately ruins the tension in the game. Is this true for Fear 3? Ha, there was little horror left in the game other than the obvious jump scares and random moving chairs. Fear 3 is BARELY a horror game. It's more of a creepy looking game with gore and guns.

But the strange thing is... I like it. I enjoyed running around wrecking my enemies. They never stood a GHOST of a chance! (That there is a Paxton Fettel joke... because he is dead) While I enjoyed the game, playing single player alone just didn't cut it for me. It wasn't worth spending the money on it at that point. However, co-op is where I was sold on this game.

In co-op one person takes on the mute, bullet dodging hitman called... Point man (yeah screw good names!) and the other takes on the role of the invulnerable ghost of Paxton Fettel. Point man can basically bullet time his way around the place while Paxton, being the what is basically the most powerful psychic person in this universe, can take over bodies at will and have a taste of what it is like being a weak Point Man. Now I know this sounds kind of terrible but playing as Paxton gives you so many options. You can be a great support for Point Man. You can outright blast enemies or take them over as your temporary body. Now staying within the body is not forever and you will have to get another but until then, enjoy the shoot 'em up. While you would think being Point man sucks, it does have it's high points. You easily can get mechs, powersuits and other cool gadgets to take over and run wild in. (Paxton can get them as well by the way but he might bleed out before getting into one)

Working as a team and dealing with all of the different difficult enemies thrown your way is really crazy fun. I enjoyed the feel of the weapons and how enemies reacted. You blast an enemy with a shotgun and he either gets knocked back or becomes bits. Shooting limbs and heads feel really good in the game, if not very rewarding.

There is collectables that are actually important as well! You basically get these to increase the time in which you can either be in slow motion or take over a body.

Now the story is forgettable at best as, I only remember the Brother" jokes I was making as I pointed to my forehead (Again

reviewText:
What's great is that you get to play as Fettel. Assuming the role of Point Man gets you a fun fast-paced shooter with unalienable slo-mo. But playing as Fettel nets you the ability to possess enemies, and when they expire - they explode in a burst of blood!

The game's length is on the shorter end of the spectrum, but on the bright side - you can finish the whole thing in co-op mode in a single afternoon. Additionally, the co-op mode is a great boost to the replay value.

This game as not as creepy-scary as the original, and I started to get skeptical about the amount of scares - until I started interval 4 (the suburbs). This interval alone is worth the money in my opinion; that was the best of classic FEAR!

The controls are very convenient, enabling the player to assign the same key to mutually-exclusive actions (for the most part). Audio is solid; soundtrack is non-invasive and at times feels very right for the circumstances.

To sum it up, this game is a fun fast-paced shooter, and can be enjoyed not just by the FEAR veterans, but also the FEAR newbies.

reviewText: If you play this game, please play it with a friend.  It was FANTASTIC to play it with someone I know.  The game is quite short if you go straight through the campaign (5-6 hours), so I would recommend getting it on sale.  This game has jump scares, it has camp, it has a terrible pun.  It was SO FUN that I have a new love for the F.E.A.R. series.  I was cracking up throughout the game on voice chat with my friend.  If you play it with someone you know, I think it has some good replayability.\nThe co-op is alot of fun!  Very different play styles depending on if you are Point Man or Fettel.  There are also opportunities to compliment one another as well as opportunities to compete against each other.  Seriously, I had a great time with this game.

reviewText: If you do want this game, DO NOT GO IN EXPECTING A HORROR GAME. It may just be me, but I kept missing the scares. I know they're there because I see them disapear and other times they just weren't scary at all. There are a few fairly creepy moments and there were others that were mildly amusing. If you want a horror game, this isn't the game for you. Now lets get on to the shooting bits. The gunplay just doesn't feel all that good. I don't feel like I'm firing a gun at all. The weapons aren't fun to fire and are fairly generic. The last bad thing about this game is its extremely linear but I guess thats to be expected from fps now days. The only redeming feature is fettel that I found really fun to play as during the combat sections.

reviewText:
Well, let's beginn with the gameplay.
It's actually good but, it is not the FEAR we know.
It dissapointed me pretty fast and it is a big dissapointment for me.
Graphics: They're good too but it could be better to be honest.
The rest: Fun for people who prefers shooter more than horror.
There is a big distance between FEAR 2 and 3 in my eyes and I still prefer FEAR 2.
But who ever likes shooters with or without friends, should buy it.
Who thinks that it is like FEAR 2, well, it will dissapoint you.
6/10 by me

reviewText: This is the 2nd time I play F.E.A.R. 3"
date:
and I still think it is a good game. If you've played the earlier games you should pick this one up and see the story through since it is not likely there will be more games in the future.

"Day 1 Studios" took over the helm from "Monolith" and "Time Gate Studios" and did an excellent job. The graphics are pretty nice and the controls are more responsive than ever before in any "F.E.A.R."-game.

The level design was also better than previous games with more varied maps.

+ Nice ending to a good FPS-series.
+ Fun gameplay.
+ Slow-Mo (need I say more).
+ The pointsystem.

- Some of the cutscenes are a bit lenghty.
- Some enemies have bad Ai.
- From what I could see
recommended: you can not play as Fettel in SP-mode."
